30. A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of fever and rash for 2 days . He just completed a 6-week course of nafcillin for treatment of staphylococcal bacterial endocarditis. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F) .
Examination shows a faint maculopapular rash . Cardiac examination shows an unchanged murmur of aortic insufficiency and no embolic lesions . Laboratory studies and an x-ray of the chest show no abnormalities . Which of the
following is the most likely set of findings on urinalysis?
Specific WBC RBC Other
Gravity Glucose Protein /hpf /hpf Casts Findings

question_stem:
the most likely set of findings on urinalysis?
Specific WBC RBC Other
Gravity Glucose Protein /hpf /hpf Casts Findings

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Interstitial nephritis is a cause of intrinsic renal failure, and often occurs secondary to medication use, with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, antibiotics, and sulfas being common precipitants. It is characterized by decreased glomerular filtration rate, rising creatinine, and eosinophilic infiltrates seen on biopsy and detected on urinalysis. Patients will have a history of medication exposure and classically present with low grade fever and diffuse rash. Urinalysis typically reveals eosinophiluria, with occasional WBC casts, increased WBC/hpf, and proteinuria. Treatment involves discontinuing the inciting agent. lncorrectAnswers:A, C, D, E, and F. Acute tubular necrosis often follows an ischemic or nephrotoxic insult and is commonly seen in patients with cardiac arrest following prolonged resuscitation prior to return of spontaneous circulation and in patients with prolonged cardiogenic, obstructive, distributive, or hypovolemic shock. Nephrotoxic agents such as heavy metals and myoglobin can also precipitate acute tubular necrosis. It is characterized on urinalysis by proteinuria, increased WBC/hpf, muddy brown casts, and visualized tubular epithelial cells on urine microscopy {Choice A). Choice C generally reflects a normal urinalysis, with specific gravity, glucose, protein, white and red cells, and casts all within normal limits. Choice D may reflect pyelonephritis, as WBC casts and bacteria are present. Classically, the number of white cells per high power field along with leukocyte esterase and nitrites are also increased in pyelonephritis. Nephritic syndrome typically presents with red blood cell casts and hematuria {Choice E). Choice F may reflect poorly controlled diabetes or a patient taking a sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 inhibitor (e.g., canagliflozin) based on the presence of glucosuria, along with a concomitant urinary tract infection given the presence of increased WBCs and bacteria. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 31 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment X 31 . A 47-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressive fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion . He has not had difficulty breathing at night or chest pain. In addition to a heart murmur that was diagnosed when he was in high school , he has diverticulosis and mild osteoarthritis . He takes no medications except a daily multivitamin . He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m 2 His temperature is • 37°C (98.6°F) , pulse is 82/min , respirations are 18/min , and blood pressure is 135/90 mm Hg.There is no jugular venous distention . The carotid pulse has a slow upstroke . The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard best at the right sternal border and radiates to the apex. There is no change in the murmur with the Valsalva maneuver . There is a paradoxical splitting of S and a prominent apical impulse . An ECG shows left 2 ventricular hypertrophy ; there is no evidence of infarction . Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's heart murmur? A) Atrial septal defect B) Congenital bicuspid aortic valve C) Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy D) Myxomatous degeneration of mitral valve E) Rheumatic heart disease Correct Answer: B. Congenital bicuspid aortic valve classically presents with early signs and symptoms of aortic stenosis and left-sided diastolic heart failure. Patients may complain of fatigue, shortness of breath, cough, diminished exercise tolerance, or syncope with exertion. Exam findings include a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur best heard at the upper right sternal border, and pulsus parvus et tardus (weak and delayed) may be noted on examination of peripheral pulses. Because of the chronic increased afterload from a fixed obstruction by the valve, left ventricular hypertrophy and resultant diastolic dysfunction can occur. If early aortic stenosis occurs, the patient may be a candidate for aortic valve replacement. lncorrectAnswers:A, C, D, and E. Atrial septal defect (Choice A) presents with fixed splitting of the S heart sound and is caused by a failure of closure of the embryologic connection between the right and left atria. Blood generally flows from the left 2 atrium into the right atrium, increasing the amount within the right heart and pulmonary circuit. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (Choice C) classically presents with a systolic murmur loudest in the lower left sternal border, which is quieter with increased preload and afterload. It is caused by hypertrophy of the septum, creating an outflow obstruction within the left ventricular outflow tract. It classically presents with syncope or sudden cardiac death in an exercising young athlete with a family history of a similar event. Myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve (Choice D) can eventually lead to mitral insufficiency, which presents with a holosystolic murmur; however, this condition would not be expected to cause left ventricular hypertrophy or pulsus parvus et tardus. Rheumatic heart disease (Choice E) commonly causes insufficiency murmurs in the acute phase and stenotic murmurs later in life, predominantly affecting the mitral valve. Rheumatic fever typically presents with joint inflammation, pancarditis, subcutaneous inflammatory nodules, erythema marginatum, and Sydenham chorea. Mitral stenosis itself presents with a diastolic murmur radiating to the axilla. If severe enough, it can result in left atrial enlargement, cardiogenic pulmonary edema, and arrhythmias such as atrial fibrillation and flutter. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 32 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment X

Three days ago , she started treatment with erythromycin for fever and cough productive of yellow sputum , but she discontinued the medication 24 hours later because of nausea and vomiting . She has autoimmune hepatitis
that has been in remission for 3 years . She appears lethargic . Her temperature is 39°C (102 .2°F) , pulse is 120/min , respirations are 32/min , and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. There is dullness to percussion over the left

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Pleural effusions are caused by multiple underlying conditions including infection such as pneumonia, malignancy such as lung cancer or mesothelioma, and increased hydrostatic pressure such as left-sided heart failure. They are clinically suspected on exam in the setting of dullness to percussion and diminished breath sounds and can be visualized on imaging including chest x-ray, CT scan, or ultrasound. Analyzing the pleural fluid can reveal an underlying cause to guide therapy. Fluid is inspected for cell counts, organisms, pH, glucose, total protein, and enzyme levels. Low pH and low glucose are indicative of increased cellular metabolism in the fluid and may indicate underlying malignancy and/or infection. Effusions can be further categorized as transudates (eg, serous fluid resulting from imbalanced hydrostatic or oncotic pressure) or exudates (eg, complex fluid resulting from pneumonia, empyema, malignancy, or inflammatory disease) using Light's criteria, which compares the pleural fluid protein and lactate dehydrogenase levels to those found in serum. Pneumonia can be complicated by simple parapneumonic exudative effusions, which, if sufficiently large, can compress lung parenchyma and impair respiratory mechanics. If not treated, secondary infection can occur within the pleural space leading to an empyema which requires evacuation via a chest tube or surgery in addition to continued antibiotic therapy. Empyema is characterized by an exudative effusion with increased pleural fluid leukocytes, low pH, low glucose, increased protein, and increased lactate dehydrogenase.

distractor_explanations.A: she would not likely require admission to the coronary care unit as she does not present with a primary cardiac pathology. Instillation of talc in the pleural space (Choice C) is used to fuse the visceral and parietal pleura (pleurodesis) in patients with recurrent pneumothoraces or symptomatic malignant pleural effusions. It has no role in the r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 32 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment y g 11 I , , 4 Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? A) Admission to the coronary care unit B Chest tube placemen t 1 C) Instillation of talc in the pleural space D) Intravenous corticosteroid therapy E) Intravenous heparin therapy F) Oral naproxen therapy G) Pericardiocentesis H) Surgical repair Correct Answer: B. Pleural effusions are caused by multiple underlying conditions including infection such as pneumonia, malignancy such as lung cancer or mesothelioma, and increased hydrostatic pressure such as left-sided heart failure. They are clinically suspected on exam in the setting of dullness to percussion and diminished breath sounds and can be visualized on imaging including chest x-ray, CT scan, or ultrasound. Analyzing the pleural fluid can reveal an underlying cause to guide therapy. Fluid is inspected for cell counts, organisms, pH, glucose, total protein, and enzyme levels. Low pH and low glucose are indicative of increased cellular metabolism in the fluid and may indicate underlying malignancy and/or infection. Effusions can be further categorized as transudates (eg, serous fluid resulting from imbalanced hydrostatic or oncotic pressure) or exudates (eg, complex fluid resulting from pneumonia, empyema, malignancy, or inflammatory disease) using Light's criteria, which compares the pleural fluid protein and lactate dehydrogenase levels to those found in serum. Pneumonia can be complicated by simple parapneumonic exudative effusions, which, if sufficiently large, can compress lung parenchyma and impair respiratory mechanics. If not treated, secondary infection can occur within the pleural space leading to an empyema which requires evacuation via a chest tube or surgery in addition to continued antibiotic therapy. Empyema is characterized by an exudative effusion with increased pleural fluid leukocytes, low pH, low glucose, increased protein, and increased lactate dehydrogenase. Incorrect Answers: A, C, D, E, F, G, and H. This patient may require admission to an intensive care unit due to the severity of illness and potential requirement for advanced therapy and frequent monitoring; however, she would not likely require admission to the coronary care unit (Choice A) as she does not present with a primary cardiac pathology. Instillation of talc in the pleural space (Choice C) is used to fuse the visceral and parietal pleura (pleurodesis) in patients with recurrent pneumothoraces or symptomatic malignant pleural effusions. It has no role in the management of empyema. Intravenous corticosteroid therapy (Choice D) may be a useful adjunct to reduce the burden of pulmonary inflammation and improve respiratory mechanics, though it offers no benefit for infectious source control and is not the most appropriate next step. Intravenous heparin therapy (Choice E) is used to treat thrombotic states such as myocardial infarction and thromboembolic disease (eg, deep venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolism). It does not have an immediate role in the management of pneumonia, pleural effusion, or empyema. Oral naproxen therapy (Choice F) has a role in the treatment of pleurisy and fever but offers only symptomatic benefit in this case.
distractor_explanations.G: Pericardiocentesis is appropriate for pericardia! tamponade or in the workup of a pericardia! effusion. Surgical repair (Choice H) would be appropriate if an esophageal or diaphragmatic rupture were suspected as the cause of the patient's pleural effusion or if a bronchopleural fistula, lung abscess, or persistent empyema developed. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 33 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment X

vignette.presentation:
33. A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe substernal chest pain for 2 hours and severe shortness of breath for 30 minutes. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with an oral
hypoglycemic agent and hypertension treated with a diuretic . His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F) , pulse is 104/min , respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 100/78 mm Hg. Jugular venous pressure is increased . Bilateral
crackles are heard throughout all lung fields. An S and S gallop are heard. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88% . An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral perihilar infiltrates and a slightly enlarged cardiac
3 4
silhouette. An ECG shows ST-segment elevation and T-wave inversion in leads V through Vs- Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
2

question_stem:
the most likely diagnosis?
2

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Myocardial infarction classically presents with acute-onset chest pain, often radiating to the neck, jaw, or arm, along with shortness of breath, nausea, and/or light-headedness. Risk factors include a history of smoking, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and/or obesity. If the infarction results in left ventricular dysfunction, patients may experience cardiogenic pulmonary edema resulting in shortness of breath, tachypnea, hypoxia, audible crackles, and an S or S gallop. Diagnosis is made using clinical history, analysis of cardiac biomarkers, and an ECG which may show ST-segment elevation or depression, inverted T-waves, or Q 3 4 waves. Treatment requires the use of antiplatelet agents (eg, aspirin, clopidogrel) plus anticoagulants (eg, heparin), pain control, and revascularization through angioplasty, thrombolysis, or coronary artery bypass grafting. Complications include dysrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, pulmonary edema, wall rupture, and post-infarction pericarditis.

distractor_explanations.A: Acute pericarditis occurs because of an infectious, inflammatory, or malignant precipitant, and presents as pleuritic chest pain that is exacerbated with lying down. ECG findings include diffuse (not focal) ST elevations and PR depressions. Pericardia! tamponade (Choice C) presents with hypotension, shortness of breath, distant heart sounds, jugular venous distention, and pulsus paradoxus. It occurs following accumulation of either a large volume or rapid-onset pericardia! effusion. Rapid decompression of the pericardia! space is required to prevent ongoing shock. The ECG is typically low voltage and can demonstrate electrical alternans.
distractor_explanations.D: Pneumonia presents with cough, shortness of breath, pleuritic chest pain, fever, and abnormal breath sounds. It often follows an upper respiratory infection or aspiration event and is more common in immunocompromised persons. The ECG is often unremarkable, and the chest x-ray can be normal early in the course but may show patchy multifocal infiltrates or a single area of consolidation. Pulmonary embolism (Choice E) presents with acute chest pain, shortness of breath, and hypoxia, often in a patient with deep venous thrombosis or a known hypercoagulable state. Small pulmonary emboli are often undetectable on chest x-ray, and the ECG may be normal or show sinus tachycardia. Large emboli with infarction are often seen on chest x-ray by secondary signs such as wedge-shaped areas of infarction or via the Westermark sign of unilateral oligemia. The ECG in a pulmonary embolus often shows sinus tachycardia, and if there is right heart strain can also exhibit right axis deviation, S wave in lead 1, Q wave in lead 3, and inverted Twave in lead 3 ('S1Q3T3'). ST segment elevation would not be expected. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 34 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment X

vignette.presentation:
34. An 87-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for treatment of a right femoral neck fracture sustained when he fell down a staircase . He has osteoarthritis of the knees treated with ibuprofen (400 mg three times daily) . He takes
no other medications. He also reports memory loss , particularly in remembering the names of people he has met recently. He first noted the problem 4 years ago , and he states that it is slowly becoming worse . There is no family
history of dementia . He lives alone , drives a car, does his own shopping and cooking , and manages his own finances . He does not smoke cigarettes . He drinks one beer daily. His blood pressure is 138/88 mm Hg. Examination
shows shortening and external rotation of the right lower extremity . Neurologic examination shows no focal findings . His Mini-Mental State Examination score is 27/30 . Which of the following is the most likely cause of this
patient's memory loss?

question_stem:
the most likely cause of this
patient's memory loss?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Mild forgetfulness without significant impairment in ability to perform instrumental activities of daily living, with a Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score of 27/30, is most consistent with mild cognitive impairment (MCI). MCI is often seen prior to a diagnosis of dementia, especially Alzheimer type, and includes amnestic (memory-related) and non-amnestic (language, spatial, executive functional impairment) MCI with generally preserved ability to function independently without significant impairment. lncorrectAnswers:A, B, D, and E. Dementia, Alzheimer type (Choice A) is defined by the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders - fifth edition (DSM-5) as loss of intellectual function within multiple domains: language, memory, perception, motor skills, attention, orientation, problem solving, and executive function. Presumptive diagnosis involves demonstrating cognitive impairment, often through the MMSE, excluding similar syndromes (e.g., vascular dementia, Lewy Body dementia) and secondary causes such as toxic (e.g., heavy metal poisoning), metabolic (e.g., electrolyte disturbances, uremia, hyperammonemia, vitamin deficiencies), endocrine (e.g., thyroid, adrenal, and parathyroid derangement), infectious (e.g., neurosyphilis, HIV encephalopathy, meningoencephalitis), polypharmaceutical (e.g., sedative-hypnotic and anticholinergic use), and superimposed psychiatric causes (e.g., major depressive disorder). Medication adverse effect (Choice B) is a well-recognized cause of cognitive impairment that is often reversible in elderly persons. Anticholinergics and sedative-hypnotics are frequently cited as causing depressed mental status or delirium when administered to persons with limited cognitive reserve. This patient does not clearly have an abrupt cognitive decline correlated with initiating such medications. Multi-infarct (vascular) dementia (Choice D) is characterized as a stepwise decline in cognitive functioning following vascular phenomena, for example, presenting as progressive loss of function after each cerebrovascular accident in a series of ischemic strokes. Vitamin B (cobalamin) deficiency (Choice E) presents with dementia resulting from nutritional deficiency and is often accompanied by megaloblastic anemia. 12 r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 35 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment X

vignette.presentation:
35. A 64-year-old woman with a 4-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with insulin comes to the emergency department because of exertional chest pressure for 3 weeks. The first episode occurred while she was
walking upstairs and was relieved by 5 minutes of rest. The second episode occurred 1 week ago while she was mowing the lawn and was relieved after 10 minutes of rest. She had two episodes yesterday , each lasting
15 minutes; both occurred with exertion and were accompanied by shortness of breath and nausea . Today she had a 10-minute episode starting while she was in the shower and another while she was walking into the
emergency department. Examination and an ECG show no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Self-monitoring of blood glucose concentration during the next episode of chest pain
Antianginal drug therapy now and an exercise stress test in 5 days
Admit the patient to the hospital

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Exertional chest pain accompanied by shortness of breath that improves with rest is suggestive of stable angina pectoris, caused by cardiac ischemia from insufficient perfusion during exertion through narrowed coronary arteries. This patient presents with worsening symptoms of angina, occurring more frequently and for a longer duration of time. This is consistent with unstable angina, defined by anginal symptoms that are new, occur at rest, or are worsening in severity. Unstable angina is a type of acute coronary syndrome, which requires admission to the hospital and urgent diagnostic workup, including serial ECGs, troponin testing, cardiology consultation, and stress test or cardiac catheterization. Patients with unstable angina are stratified based upon the Thrombolysis in Myocardial Infarction (TIMI) score, which assists in identifying the need for therapeutic anticoagulation and coronary angiography.

distractor_explanations.A: monitoring of blood glucose concentration during the next episode of chest pain would not be sufficient for workup of this patient's unstable angina and acute coronary syndrome. This patient's symptoms are unlikely to be associated with hyper- or hypoglycemia. The patient will require admission to the hospital for further monitoring and diagnostic workup. Nonexertional tests, such as dipyridamole-thallium-201 scintigraphy (Choice B), are used to evaluate cardiac perfusion in patients who are unable to exercise. Exercise stress test within 24 hours (Choice C) may be indicated, but first, the patient must be urgently admitted to the hospital for further diagnostic workup and management of unstable angina and acute coronary syndrome. Once further diagnostic tests are completed, the patient's risk can be further delineated using the TIMI score to determine the next most appropriate step in management, which may include stress testing and/or coronary angiography. Antianginal drug therapy now and an exercise stress test in 5 days (Choice D) would unnecessarily delay diagnostic workup of this patient's acute coronary syndrome, which may require coronary angiography and revascularization. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 36 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
36. A 48-year-old man with alcoholism is brought to the emergency department confused and drowsy 1 hour after he was found
on the ground in a park. Examination shows a lateral gaze defect. He has a wide-based ataxic gait. His blood alcohol
concentration is less than 0.10 mg/dl. Administration of which of the following is the most appropriate intervention?

question_stem: the most appropriate intervention?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Wernicke encephalopathy is characterized by the triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia. It occurs due to the neurologic consequences from deficiency of vitamin B (thiamine). Patients with alcohol use disorder may 1 mount symptoms of Wernicke encephalopathy because of malnutrition secondary to preferential and chronic alcohol consumption. Wernicke encephalopathy is theoretically reversible with administration of high-dose thiamine; if untreated, it can progress to Korsakoff syndrome which is characterized by dementia, confabulation, hallucinations, and psychosis. The symptoms of Wernicke encephalopathy can mimic alcohol intoxication; however, patients will have a low or undetectable serum ethanol level.

distractor_explanations.B: The symptoms of hypoglycemia often include confusion and neurologic deficits such as ataxia; however, this patient's presentation is more likely related to a deficiency in vitamin B It is important to replenish 1 thiamine with glucose in any patient with alcohol use disorder and hypoglycemia, as relative deficiency of thiamine can theoretically precipitate Wernicke encephalopathy. Vitamin B (Choice D) deficiency is also common in alcohol use disorder; however, it more commonly presents 6 with neuropathy, dermatitis, glossitis, and seizures . Vitamin B {Choice E) deficiency presents with megaloblastic anemia and neurologic deficits including 12 presentations such as subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord and possible dementia, often in a patient with risk factors for vitamin B deficiency such as patients presenting with veganism, malnutrition, Crohn 12 disease, or pernicious anemia. ,. explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Type 2 diabetes mellitus is common and is caused by increased resistance to insulin signaling. It most frequently occurs in older, obese, and sedentary persons. Type 2 diabetes can be asymptomatic until complications arise as a result of increased blood sugar, which makes screening important. It can be diagnosed through increased Hemoglobin A oral glucose tolerance testing, a random glucose greater than 200 10 mg/dl with symptoms, or via increased fasting blood glucose greater than 126 mg/dl. Control of blood sugar is important to prevent microvascular complications such as retinopathy, nephropathy, and neuropathy.

distractor_explanations.A: Cushing syndrome occurs because of increased cortisol levels and presents with truncal weight gain, fatty deposits around the face and neck, striae, acne, and muscle weakness; vital signs are notable for hypertension, and laboratory workup often reveals hyperglycemia, leukocytosis, and derangements in sodium, bicarbonate, and potassium.
distractor_explanations.B: Glucagonoma is a rare functional malignancy that secretes glucagon, which raises blood glucose through its normal mechanism of action. Occasionally, glucagonoma can present as a component of multiple endocrine neoplasia. Symptoms are nonspecific and include mild diabetes mellitus and occasionally paraneoplastic rash (e.g., necrolytic migratory erythema) and weight loss. It is not the most likely cause of increased glucose in an older, overweight person with a history of hypertension.
distractor_explanations.C: Pheochromocytoma is a rare adrenal malignancy that produces catecholamines. Symptoms include paroxysms of anxiety, agitation, diaphoresis, palpitations, tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypertension.
distractor_explanations.D: Somatostatinoma is an uncommon pancreatic malignancy that presents with weight loss, mild diabetes mellitus caused by the suppression of insulin by somatostatin, steatorrhea caused by limited cholecystokinin release, and achlorhydria from inhibition of gastrin. As with many pancreatic malignancies, it is often diagnosed late in its course. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 38 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment X

vignette.presentation:
38. A 27-year-old man is found to have a total serum cholesterol concentration of 190 mg/dl at a routine examination . He has no family history of hypertension or premature coronary artery disease. His grandmother was diagnosed
with type 2 diabetes mellitus at the age of 65 years . Examination shows no abnormalities . In addition to general dietary advice and education concerning risk factors , which of the following is the most appropriate next step in
management?

question_stem:
the most appropriate next step in
management?

choices.text: Repeat measurement of serum cholesterol concentration in 5 years
Recommend the American Heart Association Step 2 cholesterol-lowering diet

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Disease (ASCVD) has multiple risk factors, including uncontrolled hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, obesity, excess alcohol consumption, family history, age, and smoking. Reducing ASCVD is a key step in reducing the likelihood of delayed complications such as heart attacks and strokes. The 2019 guideline from the American Heart Association and American College of Cardiology (AHA/ACC Guideline on the Primary Prevention of Cardiovascular Disease) states that persons with known ASCVD, such as those having experienced a heart attack or stroke, should be started on a high-intensity statin. The guideline makes several recommendations of moderate or high-intensity statin therapy for persons ages 40 to 75 years at risk for ASCVD based on personal medical history, family history, and laboratory evaluation. Routine screening for persons under age 40 years is generally not recommended apart from reasonable surveillance every 4 to 6 years. Those persons ages 20 to 39 years who are not at an increased risk (below 7.5% risk in the next 10 years), a lifetime or 30-year risk target is reasonable in deciding whether or not to initiate lipid-lowering therapy. Lifestyle modification should always be recommended including weight loss, cardiovascular exercise, smoking cessation, safe alcohol consumption, sleep hygiene, and dietary modification for all persons with an increased level of cholesterol or those at risk for ASCVD. While this patient has increased cholesterol, he has no other obvious personal or family risk factors. Lifestyle modifications should be recommended with routine screening and initiation of lipid lowering therapy if his risk subsequently rises.

distractor_explanations.B: lowering diet is aligned to 2019 recommendations from the American Heart Association. General dietary advice and education has already been provided to the patient. Glucose tolerance testing (Choice C) is appropriate for patients in whom a diagnosis of diabetes mellitus is in question. In 2015, the United States Preventive Services Task Force presented a Grade B recommendation for screening for diabetes mellitus in adult patients ages 40 to 70 years. This patient may eventually require screening or diagnosis but does not meet criteria at this time. X-ray of the chest (Choice D) is used to diagnose various cardiothoracic conditions; it is no longer recommended for routine screening. ECG (Choice E) is used to diagnose conditions including but not limited to cardiac arrhythmias, conduction deficits, and myocardial ischemia. ECGs are occasionally used as preoperative screening but are not currently recommended for routine screening in asymptomatic individuals not under investigation for cardiovascular disease. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 39 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
39. A 65-year-old woman has fatigue, pallor, and glossitis. Hemoglobin concentration is 8 g/dL , and mean corpuscular volume is 115 µm 3 Leukocyte and platelet counts are normal. A
•
blood smear is shown . Which of the following is the most likely primary pathophysiologic mechanism causing her anemia?

question_stem: the most likely primary pathophysiologic mechanism causing her anemia?

choices.text: Unbalanced synthesis of a- and 13-globulinc hains
Measurement of serum troponin I concentration
Placement of an intraluminal esophageal stent
Placement of a left chest tube
Operative repair of the esoRhageal injury

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Impaired DNA synthesis occurs in the setting of megaloblastic anemia, characterized by the presence of hypersegmented neutrophils, anemia, and increased mean cell Bd. volume (macrocytosis). Commonly, the impairment is due to the absence of required cofactors such as folic acid and cobalamin (vitamin Malnutrition and alcohol use disorder are common causes of folic acid deficiency, while conditions such as pernicious anemia, Crohn disease, and vegan ism can result in cobalamin deficiency. Symptoms include fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance, with pallor and glossitis found on physical examination. Laboratory evaluation reveals anemia, increased mean cell volume, and normal white cell and platelet indices. The presence of hypersegmented neutrophils on peripheral smear is a characteristic finding in megaloblastic anemia. Treatment includes replacing the deficient vitamin and resolving nutritional deficiencies. lncorrectAnswers:A, B, D, and E. Defective porphyrin metabolism (Choice A) is seen in porphyria. Porphyria can arise from genetic mutations, heavy metal poisoning, and as an adverse effect of some medications. It presents with anemia, and often blistering of the skin when exposed to sunlight. Faulty protein transcription (Choice B) can cause many types of anemia; examples include sickle cell anemia and pyruvate kinase deficiency, both of which typically result in hemolytic, normocytic anemias. Inadequate erythropoietin (Choice D) occurs in chronic end-stage kidney disease because of insufficient production from the peritubular capillary interstitial cells. Without erythropoietin, progenitor cells in the bone marrow are not appropriately stimulated to produce red blood cells, resulting in the development of normocytic, non-hemolytic anemia. Unbalanced synthesis of a- and b-globulin chains (Choice E) defines thalassemia, which classically presents as a microcytic anemia in persons of Mediterranean, Asian, and African descent. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 40 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment X 40 . A 77-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 3-month history of shortness of breath when she climbs stairs . Her shortness of breath resolves after 5 minutes of rest. Her last episode was 3 days ago . She has not had chest pain, palpitations , orthopnea , cough , wheezing , swelling , or difficulty sleeping . She has hypertension and gastroesophageal reflux disease . Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide , omeprazole , and a multivitamin. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 63 kg (140 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m 2 Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F) , pulse is 72/min , respirations are 12/min , and blood pressure is 144/92 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98% . There are jugular venous pulsations 3 cm above the sternal angle . The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities . An ECG shows a left bundle branch block and no primary T-wave changes, which is unchanged from an ECG 1 year ago . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to determine the cause of this patient's dyspnea? A) Measurement of serum troponin I concentration B) ECG exercise stress test C) Exercise stress echocardiography D) Ventilation-perfusion lung scans E) Coronary angiography Correct Answer: C. Stable angina is defined as chest pain (or an anginal equivalent) that occurs with exertion or stress and resolves with rest or nitroglycerin. It indicates that an obstruction to flow exists within a coronary artery (coronary artery disease), which results in myocardial ischemia during a period of increased myocardial oxygen demand. Classically, this occurs from atherosclerotic plaque causing narrowing of a coronary artery, with resultant insufficient supply of blood during periods of increased demand. If such a plaque ulcerates and a thrombus forms, complete occlusion of a coronary artery can result, which can lead to myocardial infarction. Diagnosing inducible cardiac ischemia is first attempted by way of a stress test, either through exercise or pharmacologic stress. An exercise stress echocardiography scan is appropriate for patients who are able to exercise but who have a baseline-abnormal ECG that would make a stress ECG difficult to analyze for ischemia (e.g., such as a baseline bundle-branch block that results in ST-segment repolarization change, or inverted T waves). A stress echocardiogram evaluates for regional wall motion abnormalities suggestive of regional ischemia following induction of stress on the heart via exercise. lncorrectAnswers:A, B, D, and E. Measurement of serum troponin I concentration {Choice A) is appropriate in the diagnosis of an acute coronary syndrome, blunt cardiac injury, myocarditis, or pulmonary embolism. It does not have a role in the diagnosis of stable angina if infarction, injury, or strain on the heart is not suspected. ECG exercise stress test {Choice B) is a first-line screening test in the diagnosis of cardiac ischemia from coronary artery disease, but in patients with an ST-segment baseline ECG abnormality {left or right bundle branch block, left ventricular hypertrophy, early repolarization, or ventricular aneurysm), it lacks appropriate sensitivity and specificity. Ventilation-perfusion lung scans {Choice D) are used to assess for mismatches in pulmonary ventilation and perfusion and are most commonly used as a second-line study for pulmonary embolus when a contrast enhanced CT angiogram cannot be performed. Coronary angiography {Choice E) is an invasive means of identifying coronary artery disease and is performed through arterial catheterization; it may be required in the diagnosis or treatment of coronary artery disease but would occur following initial noninvasive evaluation in patients not experiencing an acute coronary syndrome. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 41 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment X 41 . Immediately after undergoing an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy and dilatation for achalasia, a 32-year-old woman has moderate substernal and midback pain . She has no history of serious illness . Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min , respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft and nondistended . Esophagography shows a small leak of contrast from the distal esophagus into the left chest. In addition to intravenous antibiotic therapy , which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? A) Placement of an intraluminal esophageal stent B) Placement of a left chest tube C) Nissen fundoplication D) Esophagogastrectomy E) Operative repair of the esoRhageal injury Correct Answer: E. The benefits and risks of any procedure must be considered prior to undertaking the procedure. Upper endoscopy is a generally safe procedure, though complications can include bleeding, aspiration, and perforation, and depending on the purpose of the endoscopy, specific complications such as pancreatitis following endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) can occur. In the case of achalasia, the endoscopy was performed to dilate the narrowed lower esophageal sphincter to promote passage of food. Stretching of smooth muscle, stricture, and connective tissue, especially if chronic inflammation from food bolus impaction led to compromise of the stromal strength of the esophageal wall, can lead to perforation. A perforated esophagus is diagnosed on water-soluble contrast esophagography. An esophageal perforation permits translocation of gastrointestinal contents such as food, stomach acid, and bacteria into the mediastinum, which if untreated, can lead to a fatal mediastinitis infection. Management of esophageal perforation is through antibiotics plus emergent surgical repair.

distractor_explanations.A: Placement of an intraluminal esophageal stent is used to manage an esophageal obstruction, for example, from an esophageal web, stricture, or malignancy. It does not have a primary role in the management of an acute esophageal perforation. Placement of a left chest tube (Choice B) may be necessary if translocated gastric contents develop into an empyema; however, such complication would not be evident for several days and may be avoided altogether with the use of antibiotics. Nissen fundoplication (Choice C) is a primary surgical treatment for gastroesophageal reflux disease due to incompetence of the lower esophageal sphincter and involves plication of the gastric fund us around the lower esophagus. It does not have an immediate role in repairing an esophageal perforation.
distractor_explanations.D: Esophagogastrectomy constitutes the removal of a portion of the esophagus and stomach and is often performed in cases of malignancy; it would not have an immediate role in the management of an esophageal perforation. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 42 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
42. A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a lesion on the thigh for 6 months . The lesion is shown . Which of the following is the most appropriate next
step in management?

question_stem:
the most appropriate next
step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Malignant melanoma is likely to be present when a skin lesion demonstrates asymmetry, irregular-appearing borders, variable coloration, a diameter greater than 6 mm, and rapid evolution in characteristics. Malignant melanoma has the ability to rapidly invade and metastasize, which carries a poor prognosis when diagnosed late. Any lesion with features suggestive of malignant melanoma should be surgically excised with negative margins and pathologically examined for the depth of dermal invasion.

distractor_explanations.A: Observation is inappropriate, as it may result in delay in diagnosis of a potentially lethal malignancy. Radiation therapy (Choice B) may be necessary in treating malignant melanoma, but a diagnosis must first be established. Laser ablation (Choice C) is more frequently used to treat benign cosmetic lesions and would not have a role in the immediate management of malignant melanoma. Electrodessication and curettage (Choice D) may not effectively examine the margins of the lesion, which are important in determining extent of invasion and prognosis. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 43 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment X 43 . A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of pain of the fingertips for 1 month . Examination shows plethora and splenomegaly . Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 20.2 g/dL Leukocyte count 14,500/mm 3 with a normal differential Platelet count 400 ,000/mm J Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows : Po 92 mm Hg 2 0 saturation 94% 2 Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? A) Administration of chlorambucil B) Administration of heparin C) Thrombopheresis D) Phlebotomy E) Splenectomy CorrectAnswer: D. Polycythemia vera is a chronic myeloproliferative disorder resulting in increased production of all cell lineages (erythrocyte, leukocyte, and thrombocyte) secondary to a JAK2 mutation. It presents with pruritus, especially after hot showers, secondary to increased mast cell production and degranulation. Additionally, it can present with episodic severe, burning pain with red-blue discoloration secondary to blood clot formation in extremity vessels, referred to as erythromelalgia. The marked increase in red blood cell production and hematocrit can lead to the development of hyperviscosity syndrome, which presents with blurred vision and central nervous system symptoms related to vascular congestion. Examination can show splenomegaly and congestion of vessels seen as plethora. Therapeutic phlebotomy results in decreased red blood cell mass and blood volume, which is the best initial treatment for the patient's symptoms. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and E. Administration of chlorambucil (Choice A) is used to treat chronic lymphocytic leukemia, Hodgkin disease, and non-Hodgkin lymphoma. This patient's presentation is most consistent with polycythemia vera. Administration of heparin (Choice B) is appropriate in cases of arterial or venous thrombosis; while this patient may eventually develop a thrombus that requires anticoagulation, at this time there is no evident role for this medication.
distractor_explanations.C: Thrombopheresis is the selective removal of platelets from blood and is performed during platelet-specific donation or to treat conditions of excess platelets such as essential thrombocythemia when other cell lines are not similarly increased.
distractor_explanations.E: Splenectomy may have a role in treating patients with polycythemia vera if they have painful splenomegaly or splenic infarction, but barring such complications, it is not a routine next step in the management of polycythemia vera. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 44 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment X 44 . A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing nocturnal incontinence that began 2 months ago and now occurs nightly. He has a 20-year history of hypertension treated with verapamil. He has been taking amitriptyline for major depressive disorder since his wife died 3 months ago . His blood pressure is 158/78 mm Hg. There is lower abdominal distention with diffuse tenderness to palpation . Rectal examination shows a moderately enlarged , smooth prostate with no stool in the vault. Neurologic examinations show no abnormalities . Laboratory studies show : Serum creatinine 1.6 mg/dl Urine Protein 1+ WBC 1-2/hpf RBC 2-4/hpf Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A) Benign prostatic hy erplasia B) Cauda equina syndrome C) Dementia , Alzheimer type D) Normal-pressure hydrocephalus E) Urinary tract infection Correct Answer: A. Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) affects middle-aged and elderly male patients, occurring because of excess growth of tissue in the central prostate causing a lower urinary tract obstruction. BPH presents with urinary dribbling and incontinence, difficulty starting or maintaining a urinary stream, nocturia, the need to frequently urinate, and incomplete voiding. These symptoms are typically insidious in onset, chronic, and progressive. Diagnosis is made on history, physical, and urodynamic testing, along with ruling out alternate diagnoses (eg, prostatic malignancy). Treatment is with supportive care, alpha blockers, 5-a-reductase inhibitors, and/or surgery. Incorrect Answers: B, C, D, and E. Cauda equina syndrome (Choice B) is caused by compression of the spinal nerve roots comprising the cauda equina. Often, such compression occurs because of malignancy, trauma (eg, compression fractures with fragment retropulsion), disc herniation, spinal stenosis, spinal epidural abscess, or spinal epidural or subdural hematoma. Symptoms include lower extremity numbness, weakness, paralysis, hyporeflexia, perinea! anesthesia, fecal incontinence with poor rectal tone, and overflow incontinence marked by inability to void. Dementia, Alzheimer type (Choice C) may present with urinary symptoms in a behavioral context such as volitional voiding at inappropriate times or in inappropriate locations. This patient is not showing any signs of dementia. Normal-pressure hydrocephalus (Choice D) presents with symptoms of dementia, urinary incontinence, and ataxia. Urinary tract infection (Choice E) presents with urinary incontinence, dysuria, frequency, urgency, and suprapubic discomfort. It is more common in women than men. Urinalysis typically demonstrates greater than 10 leukocytes per high-power field. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 45 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment X

vignette.presentation:
45. A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of pain and swelling of her knees. She says she also has had stiffness of her knees, which is worse in the morning . During the past month , she has had
progressive , generalized fatigue . On examination , the knees are warm , swollen , and tender. Any attempt at passive movement of the knees produces pain. Her hemoglobin concentration is 10 g/dl , leukocyte count is
10,000/mm 3 and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 50 mm/h. X-rays of the knees show osteopenia and subcartilaginous cysts around the joints . The joint spaces are intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate
pharmacotherapy?

question_stem:
the most appropriate
pharmacotherapy?

choices.text: Application of ice packs to the breasts

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Pain and swelling of joints, morning stiffness, fatigue, mild anemia, increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and x-rays showing periarticular osteopenia and erosions is concerning for an inflammatory arthropathy such as rheumatoid arthritis, pseudogout, reactive arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, or similar rheumatologic or immunologic disorder. Once secondary causes such as disseminated gonococcal arthritis, Lyme disease, and septic arthritis have been excluded, the first-line treatment is generally with a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) such as ibuprofen. lncorrectAnswers:A, B, D, and E. Oral alendronate (Choice A), a bisphosphonate osteoclast inhibitor, is used in the treatment of osteoporosis and hypercalcemia. It does not have a primary role in the management of an inflammatory arthropathy. Oral colchicine (Choice B) is used in the management of gout, pseudogout, and pericarditis. Gout and pseudogout result from deposition of crystals into the joint space, which trigger an intense inflammatory reaction. Symptoms are more often acute, monoarticular, and severe. Diagnosis is via arthrocentesis. Intra-articular injection of methylprednisolone (Choice D) may have a role in the treatment of inflammatory arthritis but would generally occur after a trial of NSAIDs; additionally, this local treatment would require multiple injections, increasing the risk of infection and discomfort to the patient. Intravenous cefazolin (Choice E) would be appropriate in some cases of septic arthritis if a susceptible pathogen were diagnosed; this patient does not clearly have septic arthritis and antibiotics are inappropriate at this time. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 46 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment X 46 . A 32-year-old woman , gravida 1, para 1, comes to the physician because of spontaneous discharge from her nipples during the past 3 months . She discontinued breast-feeding her child 1 year ago . She takes no medications . Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals . On physical examination , a milky white discharge can be expressed from both nipples. Examination shows no other abnormalities . Her fasting serum prolactin concentration is 40 ng/ml , and serum thyroid-stimulating hormone concentration is within the reference range. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient? A) Application of ice packs to the breasts B) Wearing tight bras C) Bromocriptine theraEJy D) Tamoxifen therapy E) Vitamin E therapy Correct Answer: C. An inappropriate elevation in serum prolactin is defined as hyperprolactinemia and causes production of breast milk and growth of glandular breast tissue. After cessation of breast-feeding, serum prolactin levels typically return to pre-pregnancy levels. Inappropriate elevation of prolactin often arises from a hyperfunctioning anterior pituitary microadenoma and presents with unexpected production of breast milk. Prolactin is negatively regulated by dopamine. Various dopaminergic blocking medications can have galactorrhea as an adverse effect. Further, prolactin is positively regulated by thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) and in states of hypothyroidism with upregulated TRH, galactorrhea can also occur. With exclusion of the thyroid and any contributions from dopamine antagonists, further diagnostic evaluation should include an MRI of the brain to assess for the presence of a pituitary adenoma. Treatment is with dopamine agonists such as bromocriptine or cabergoline, and if such medications fail or if a macroadenoma is found, surgical resection of the adenoma is required. lncorrectAnswers:A, B, D, and E. Application of ice packs to the breasts (Choice A) and wearing tight bras (Choice B) are recommendations offered to lactating women approaching the end of breast-feeding or for postpartum women who do not wish to pursue breast-feeding. These measures provide relief of discomfort from engorged breast tissue but have no role in treating hormonal dysregulation from pathologic hyperprolactinemia. Tamoxifen therapy (Choice D), a selective estrogen receptor modulator, is used in the treatment of estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer by blocking the trophic action of estrogen on the tumor. It has no role in treating hyperprolactinemia or a pituitary prolactinoma. Vitamin E therapy (Choice E) has been shown to lower prolactin levels in patients with uremia on hemodialysis and has been shown to have an inhibitory effect on pituitary gland hypertrophy; in spite of these findings, it has not been shown to be as effective when compared to dopamine agonists and surgical resection. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 47 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment X

vignette.presentation:
47. Four days after undergoing a left total hip replacement , a 75-year-old woman has the rapid onset of chest pain, severe dyspnea, and confusion . Her pulse is 120/min, respirations are 28/min , and blood pressure is 94/60 mm Hg.
A pleural rub is heard at the right lung base. The surgical incision appears to be healing well. There is moderate edema of the left leg. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows :
pH 7.46
Pco 28 mm Hg
2
Po 62 mm Hg
2
Which of the following postoperative treatments is most likely to have prevented this condition?

question_stem: most likely to have prevented this condition?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The radial nerve courses posterior to the humerus at the midshaft within the radial groove. It is often injured in displaced midshaft humerus fractures, with resulting wrist drop. The radial nerve supplies motor fibers to the triceps brachii and the extensor muscles within the posterior compartment of the forearm and sensory fibers to the dorsum of the forearm, wrist, and hand. It does not innervate the intrinsic muscles of the hand. Injury to the nerve at the mid-diaphyseal humerus causes extensor muscle loss at the hand and wrist, weakness of forearm supination, the presence of wrist drop, and sensory loss over the posterior forearm, dorsum of the hand, and posterior thumb, index, middle, and radial-half of the ring finger.

distractor_explanations.A: Aspirin is an antiplatelet agent commonly used as prophylaxis against arterial thrombotic phenomena involving the coronary arteries (eg, myocardial infarction) and cerebral arteries (eg, cerebrovascular accidents). It does not have a recognized role in the prevention of DVT/PE. Administration of cefoxitin (Choice B), a second-generation cephalosporin, can be used for the treatment of common gram-positive, and some gram-negative pathogens, such as in pelvic inflammatory disease. It does not have a role in the prevention of DVT/PE. Administration of oxygen (Choice C) has a role in treating hypoxemia secondary to PE but has no role in the prevention of DVT/PE. Use of incentive spirometry (Choice E) has been shown to prevent post-operative atelectasis along with post-operative pneumonia. It does not have a role in the prevention of DVT/PE. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 48 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment X 48 . A 57-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. She was the restrained front seat passenger . Her neck was immobilized in a cervical collar at the scene . On arrival , she reports neck pain and pain in her right forearm . Her pulse is 80/min , respirations are 16/min , and blood pressure is 150/70 mm Hg. Examination of the right upper extremity shows swelling and crepitus . She is able to actively extend the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints but not the metacarpophalangeal joints of her right hand or wrist. The remainder of the examination shows no other abnormalities . Plain x-rays show a midshaft fracture of the humerus . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A) Brachia! plexus injury B) Compartment syndrome C) Herniated cervical disc D) Median nerve injury E) Radial nerve injury Correct Answer: E. The radial nerve courses posterior to the humerus at the midshaft within the radial groove. It is often injured in displaced midshaft humerus fractures, with resulting wrist drop. The radial nerve supplies motor fibers to the triceps brachii and the extensor muscles within the posterior compartment of the forearm and sensory fibers to the dorsum of the forearm, wrist, and hand. It does not innervate the intrinsic muscles of the hand. Injury to the nerve at the mid-diaphyseal humerus causes extensor muscle loss at the hand and wrist, weakness of forearm supination, the presence of wrist drop, and sensory loss over the posterior forearm, dorsum of the hand, and posterior thumb, index, middle, and radial-half of the ring finger. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and D. Brachia! plexus injury (Choice A), depending on the location within the plexus, would involve motor and sensory loss of multiple nerves. A mononeuropathy would be unlikely. Compartment syndrome (Choice B) presents with pain, paresthesia, paresis, poikilothermia, pallor, and pulselessness. It occurs because of increased pressure from swelling or hemorrhage within a fixed-space myofascial compartment. When the pressure approaches or exceeds diastolic blood pressure, blood flow becomes impaired. The compartment and any downstream-supplied structures can become ischemic. With an otherwise normal exam, the localization of the patient's findings to radial nerve injury is much more likely. Herniated cervical disc (Choice C) can occur from traumatic injury and is a known cause of cervical radiculopathy. Usually, one single nerve root is affected, and it commonly presents with pain in a radicular pattern. Weakness of muscles innervated by multiple cervical spinal levels would be less likely outside of catastrophic injury to the cervical spine. Median nerve injury (Choice D) presents with weakness involving the flexor compartment of the forearm, thenar eminence, and first two lumbrical muscles, along with diminished sensation over the anterior forearm and lateral hand. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 49 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment X

vignette.presentation:

temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min , respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 150/100 mm Hg. On examination , she is obtunded and confused . There is no jugular venous distention when she is supine .
Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities . There are no focal neurologic signs. Serum studies show:
Na • 146 mEq/L

5.0 mEq/L

Urea nitrogen 40 mg/dl
Glucose 105 mg/dl
Creatinine 1.8 mg/dl
Albumin 3.1 g/dl
Intravenous infusion of which of the following is the most appropriate initial therapy?

question_stem: the most appropriate initial therapy?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: lsotretinoin (retinoic acid), a derivative of vitamin A, is teratogenic to the fetus and causes multiple malformations often involving the central nervous and musculoskeletal systems. Patients taking isotretinoin for acne vulgaris should be instructed to use at least one form, ideally two forms, of contraception to prevent pregnancy and resulting teratogenic consequences for the fetus. Generally, barrier methods are considered inadequate given higher failure rates; intrauterine devices and oral contraceptive pills are preferred. The patient is sexually active without the current use of contraception, which is a contraindication to using isotretinoin.

distractor_explanations.D: are not characteristically exacerbated by the use of vitamin A derivatives and would not contraindicate the use of isotretinoin therapy in this patient. "' , r-- r ,,,

vignette.presentation:
50. A 40-year-old man with alcoholism has had a low-grade fever , malaise , and cough productive of purulent sputum for 2 weeks and hemoptysis for 24 hours ; during this period , he has had a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss . His temperature
is 37 .8°C (100°F) . Hematocrit is 33% , and leukocyte count is 15,000/mm 3 An x-ray of the chest shows a large cavitary lesion with an air-fluid level in the superior segment of the right lower lobe of the lung. Which of the following
•
is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Aspiration pneumonia is characterized by fever, cough productive of foul-smelling sputum, malaise, and chest discomfort following an aspiration event; untreated or complicated aspiration pneumonia can lead to the development of a lung abscess, especially with the pathogen Klebsiel/a pneumoniae. Patients at higher risk for aspiration include those with impaired airway-protective reflexes (eg, stroke, myasthenia gravis, depressed mental status), those with frequent or forceful emesis (eg, alcohol use disorder, cyclic vomiting syndrome), or those with abnormal pharyngeal or airway anatomy (eg, malignancy, tracheo-esophageal fistula). These patients are more likely to aspirate gastric contents into the lung, which results in bacterial seeding with gastrointestinal or oral flora and can lead to pneumonia. Frequently, aspiration occurs in a dependent segment of the lung such as bilateral lower lobes when erect or the lingula, right middle lobe, and superior segments of the lower lobes while lying down. Pulmonary abscesses often present with low-grade fevers, weight loss, anemia, and leukocytosis. On chest x-ray, air-fluid levels are seen within the abscess cavity. Treatment is with antibiotics, prevention of recurrent aspiration, and source control with surgical resection or percutaneous drainage. lncorrectAnswers:A, B, D, and E. Aspergillomas (Choice A) are fungal masses that often arise within existing cavitary lesions of the lung, such as those caused by previous infection with tuberculosis or from cavitary squamous cell lung carcinoma. Bronchiectasis (Choice B) is abnormal dilatation of the bronchi that results from recurrent necrotizing infections. Risk factors for bronchiectasis are cystic fibrosis, Kartagener syndrome, and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis. There are many types of lung cancer (Choice D), such as small cell and non-small cell carcinoma. Lung cancer often presents with hemoptysis and weight loss, but unless a superinfection were present, an air-fluid level would not be expected. Rather, a solitary nodular, mass-like opacity on a chest x-ray or CT would be a more likely presentation. Homeless persons, patients suffering from alcohol use disorder, incarcerated patients, those from endemic areas (eg, Africa, South America), and those living in close contact are more likely to contract tuberculosis (Choice E). Tuberculosis classically presents with fever, night sweats, weight loss, and hemoptysis. The chest x-ray in reactivation tuberculosis classically shows cavitary lesions in the apices of the lung, with possible evidence of a Ghon complex (pulmonary calcified granulomas and hilar adenopathy) from the prior primary tuberculous infection. r-- r " , r ,

vignette.presentation:
1. A 42-year-old man has had the gradual onset of greasy, diffuse scaling of the scalp with variable itching over the past year. Yellowish red scaling papules appear along the hairline and behind the ears; there is no hair loss . Which
of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Seborrheic dermatitis is a chronic inflammatory skin disease, which occurs in regions containing sebaceous glands. In adults, it typically presents as yellowish-red, scaly patches of the scalp and forehead, around the ears, nasolabial folds, and chest. In infants, it presents as "cradle cap," with the appearance of a diaper rash and yellow scaling on the scalp. Diffuse, severe seborrheic dermatitis can occur in immunosuppressed patients. Treatment consists of zinc pyrithione or selenium sulfide shampoo applied to the scalp along with topical antifungals such as ketoconazole. Topical corticosteroids can also be used for severe cases to decrease the inflammatory reaction and pruritus.

distractor_explanations.A: Exfoliative dermatitis is a severe inflammatory skin condition characterized by the development of generalized, diffuse erythema, and scaling with desquamation involving large areas of the body. This often occurs in the setting of pre-existing skin disorders (eg, psoriasis, eczema), cancer (eg, leukemia, lymphoma), or after administration of certain medications (eg, sulfa, penicillin, phenytoin). Lichen simplex chronicus (Choice B) is a localized region of skin thickening (lichenification) that results from repetitive rubbing or itching of the skin. Pediculosis capitis (Choice C) refers to infestation of the scalp and hair by the Pedicu/us humanus capitis (human louse), which can cause severe pruritus. Treatment includes permethrin, pyrethrins, ivermectin, or malathion lotions.
distractor_explanations.D: Psoriasis results in erythematous plaques with silvery scales that are typically located on extensor surfaces (e.g., knees, elbows). It can involve the scalp, but this is less common. r , " , F' Exam Section : Item 2 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment X

vignette.presentation:
2. A 24-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination . Two months ago , he was seen for a red, scaly rash over his groin . A 6-week course of topical clotrimazole resolved the rash completely , but it recurred 2 days
ago . He is sexually active with one partner and uses condoms consistently . Examination shows an erythematous , excoriated rash over the groin and a similar rash over the instep of the left foot. A KOH preparation of a skin
scraping shows hyphae . Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's recurrent infection?

question_stem: the most likely cause of this patient's recurrent infection?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Autoinfection of the patient's groin resulting in recurrent tinea cruris is the most likely scenario. Tinea (dermatophytosis) refers to cutaneous fungal infection with organisms such as Microsporum, Trichophyton, and Epidermophyton. These are characterized by branching septated hyphae on KOH preparation of skin scrapings. The patient exhibits a red, scaly rash in his groin (tinea cruris), which is subsequently treated with first line therapy of clotrimazole. The patient also has a similar rash on his left foot (tinea pedis), which was not treated and likely served as a source for autoinfection to other regions of the body, resulting in the patient's recurrent tinea cruris. Treatment with clotrimazole to both the groin and left foot at the same time is needed to appropriately treat the patient's multifocal tinea.

distractor_explanations.C: Impaired cellular immunity and impaired humeral immunity (Choice D) refer to an underlying immunocompromised state. While immunocompromised patients are at increased risk for disseminated dermatophytosis infections, the more likely scenario for this patient is autoinfection from an additional untreated region. Reinfection from a sexual partner (Choice E) is possible, although less likely given the patient's untreated tinea pedis source. Dermatophytes spread through contact with infected skin, including from other individuals. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 3 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment X

vignette.presentation:
3. An otherwise healthy 30-year-old man has had recurrent aching right shoulder pain initiated by reaching overhead ; it also occurs at night in bed. The pain is most prominent in the area of the deltoid muscle. It is elicited by
abduction of the shoulder against resistance . Which of the following is the most likely site of the underlying condition?

question_stem: the most likely site of the underlying condition?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The supraspinatus tendon is the most common location of rotator cuff injury. The supraspinatus muscle lies within the supraspinous fossa along the superior portion of the scapula, and its tendon inserts on the greater tuberosity of the humerus. The supraspinatus muscle contributes to initiation of arm abduction prior to the action of the deltoid muscle. Injury to the supraspinatus tendon may occur from degeneration, impingement, or trauma, and can be evaluated through abduction of the shoulder against resistance.

distractor_explanations.A: The biceps tendon consists of a short head originating from the coracoid process and a long head originating from the intra-articular supraglenoid tubercle. The biceps brachii inserts at the radial tuberosity. Injury to the biceps tendon results in weakness of elbow flexion and forearm supination. Cervical nerve root (Choice B) injury would result in neurologic symptoms such as weakness, numbness, and paresthesia along a specific dermatome and myotome. It would not be aggravated by shoulder abduction. The deltoid muscle (Choice C) is not commonly injured, much less than the supraspinatus tendon, and only contributes to abduction of the shoulder after the first 15 degrees. Proximal humerus (Choice D) injury such as a surgical neck fracture can lead to axillary nerve injury, which would result in dysfunction of the deltoid muscle and loss of sensation over the proximal lateral arm. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 4 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment X

vignette.presentation:
4. A 72-year-old woman comes to the physician because she is concerned about her high blood pressure . Two days ago , her blood pressure was 200/105 mm Hg at the drug store . She has a 20-year history of hypertension that
had been well controlled with a thiazide diuretic . At her last visit 3 months ago , her blood pressure was 140/75 mm Hg. Today, her pulse is 80/min , respirations are 12/min , and blood pressure is 210/114 mm Hg. Funduscopic
examination shows arteriovenous nicking . A right carotid bruit is heard. Laboratory studies are within normal limits . Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?

question_stem: the most likely cause of these findings?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Renal artery stenosis is a cause of secondary hypertension related to abnormal stimulation of the juxtaglomerular apparatus secondary to stenosis of the renal artery leading to insufficient afferent blood flow. This results in excessive production of renin and angiotensin. Secondary hypertension should be considered in new-onset or treatment-resistant hypertension. There are two main causes of renal artery stenosis: fibromuscular dysplasia and atherosclerosis. In younger patients, fibromuscular dysplasia is the most common cause, while older patients develop renal artery stenosis more commonly from atherosclerosis. This patient exhibits a carotid bruit, likely also secondary to atherosclerosis. Diagnosis is established with renal artery Doppler ultrasonography or magnetic resonance angiography. Treatment involves angioplasty or stenting of the stenosed renal artery to improve flow. ACE inhibitors can be considered for unilateral stenosis but can lead to acute end-stage kidney disease in the setting of bilateral renal artery stenosis.

distractor_explanations.A: Acute glomerulonephritis refers to a variety of glomerular diseases, including nephritic and nephrotic syndromes. Nephritic syndrome can result in hypertension, although this is less likely given the patient's risk factors for atherosclerosis. Acute porphyria (Choice B) presents with abdominal pain, polyneuropathy, psychological symptoms, and port wine-colored urine, not resistant hypertension. Coarctation of the aorta (Choice C) is a cause of secondary hypertension related to narrowing of the aorta, although it most commonly presents in childhood with differential blood pressure between upper and lower extremities. It is associated with bicuspid aortic valve and gonadal dysgenesis 45,X (Turner syndrome). Cushing syndrome (Choice D) results from increased cortisol levels and presents with hypertension, moon facies, abdominal striae, osteoporosis, hyperglycemia, and amenorrhea. This patient demonstrates risk factors for atherosclerosis, with no additional findings to suggest Cushing syndrome.
distractor_explanations.E: Hyperaldosteronism presents with hypertension and metabolic derangements, including hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. This can occur in the setting of an adrenal adenoma such as in Conn syndrome or from bilateral adrenal hyperplasia. Primary hyperparathyroidism (Choice F) is a potential cause of secondary hypertension and may also present with hypercalcemia and hypophosphatemia, with symptoms such as constipation, renal stones, psychiatric disturbances, and osseous lytic lesions.
distractor_explanations.G: Hyperthyroidism can result in secondary hypertension but also typically presents with heat intolerance, weight loss, diarrhea, hyperreflexia, palpitations, and myopathy.
distractor_explanations.H: Pheochromocytoma results in episodic hypertension with associated palpitations, diaphoresis, headache, and pallor. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 5 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment X

vignette.presentation:
5. A 57-year-old woman with stage IV non-small cell lung carcinoma is admitted to the hospital because of a 2-day history of shortness of breath and fever. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F) . She receives the diagnosis of
postobstructive pneumonia. Treatment with intravenous antibiotics is begun, and her symptoms resolve 3 days later. During a family meeting to discuss her treatment options, the patient states that she wishes to discontinue
chemotherapy and requests no resuscitation if she has a cardiac arrest. In addition to obtaining a signed advance directive and durable power of attorney for health care decisions, which of the following is the most appropriate
recommendation for this patient?

question_stem:
the most appropriate
recommendation for this patient?

choices.text: Discharge home with home hosl)ice care
Discharge home with physical and occupational therapy
Discharge home with visiting nurse services
Discharge to a skilled nursing care facility

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Discharge home with home hospice care is indicated for patients whose life expectancy is less than six months in the setting of a terminal diagnosis. This patient presents with stage IV non-small cell lung carcinoma and wishes to discontinue aggressive treatment such as chemotherapy. Hospice care focuses on palliation of a patient's symptoms with attention to providing comfort, rather than aggressive treatment in an attempt to cure the patient's underlying illness. Given the patient's current prognosis and stated wishes, hospice care would be the most appropriate recommendation.

distractor_explanations.B: Discharge home with physical and occupational therapy is indicated for the rehabilitation of patients following hospitalization, surgery, and/or trauma in order to improve the patient's physical abilities in an attempt to return to their daily life and work activities. This patient demonstrates the wish to discontinue aggressive therapy for her cancer, making hospice a better arrangement. Discharge home with visiting nurse services (Choice C) and discharge to a skilled nursing care facility (Choice D) are indicated for patients discharged from the hospital who need some level of nursing care to assist with the handling of their medical conditions. These services provide nursing care to assist with medications and hygiene but would not focus primarily on palliation and patient comfort like hospice care. Remain in the hospital (Choice E) would not be the best choice for this patient as it would not allow the patient to receive palliative care in the comfort of her own home. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 6 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment X

vignette.presentation:
6. An 87-year-old resident of a skilled nursing care facility is brought to the physician by staff because of a lesion on his left leg for 3 weeks . He has been confined to bed for 3 years because of a left hemiplegia following a cerebral
infarction . Examination shows a 5 x 7-cm , grade 3 pressure ulcer over the left greater trochanter; there is an overlying eschar with a small rim of erythema . There are no other areas of ulceration . Which of the following is the most
appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Application of silver sulfadiazine cream and a sterile dressing

In adults, it typically presents as yellowish-red, scaly patches of the scalp and forehead, around the ears, nasolabial folds, and chest. Topical corticosteroids can also be used for severe cases to decrease the inflammatory reaction and pruritus.
