On laboratory examination, it demonstrates low serum C3 levels, and positive anti-streptolysin O and anti-DNase titers. Renal cell carcinoma (Choice E) is an adenocarcinoma of tubular epithelial cells. Patients may present with gross hematuria (without RBC casts), flank pain, and possible palpable flank mass . Diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma typically occurs with contrast-enhanced CT or MRI and is confirmed by biopsy at the time of nephrectomy. ,. "' , r-- ,. , Exam Section : Item 20 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
20. An 82-year-old man with metastatic lung cancer is brought to the emergency department by his children because he has
been unresponsive for the past 24 hours. His family reports that he has become increasingly sleepy and confused over the
past 2 weeks. His lung cancer was diagnosed 3 years ago and initially treated with palliative radiation therapy to his chest
and right femur. Nine months ago, he and his oncologist agreed to discontinue treatment. He has had a 16-kg (35-lb) weight
loss over the past 9 months . He has lived in his son's house for the past 6 months and has received palliative care only. The
patient has an advance directive indicating that he does not want lifesaving treatment , and the son has stated that his father
recently confirmed these wishes verbally. His daughter, who lives out of state , disagrees with the plan to provide palliative
care at home only and is concerned about her father's weight loss. After a family meeting, both siblings now request that the
physician switch to an aggressive treatment plan. The patient appears cachectic but well groomed . He responds to painful
stimuli only. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 52 kg (115 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m 2 His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F),
•
pulse is 122/min, respirations are 34/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 85/50 mm Hg. Serum studies show:
Na+ 142 mEq/L
Ca2+ 13.2 mg/dl
Creatinine 2.8 mg/dl
Albumin 3 g/dl
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Perform lifesaving measures until the family issues can be resolved

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Advance directives are formal specifications of a patient's wishes, created and executed during a time of decision-making capacity. They are enacted when the patient loses capacity to communicate preferences about healthcare wishes . Often, these documents govern end-of-life care, and are commonly used in cases of terminal illness, with late-stage malignancy a very common time of use. Advance directives should reflect a patient's wishes as expressed during periods of stable values and preferences, and the medicolegal strength of an advance directive is greater when family members or persons who know the patient corroborate the document's accurate reflection of long-standing and stable wishes. In this case, this patient had an advance directive written and prepared for use in such a case, and his son, who lives locally and seems to know the patient and his preferences , corroborates what his father would have wanted. Following the advance directive is the most appropriate course of action, while showing compassion and empathy to the family.

distractor_explanations.A: Contacting the hospital attorney or ethics committee (Choice B) is unnecessary. The patient's wishes are clearly stated in his advance directive, and there is no evidence that the patient's wishes for himself have changed since the time of drafting and execution. The patient has clearly stated that he does not want lifesaving measures (Choice D), and he and his oncology team had also agreed that aggressive care (Choice E) would be futile given the extent and aggressive nature of his malignancy. ,. "' , r-- r ,,, Exam Section : Item 21 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
21. A 42-year-old African American woman comes to the physician because of a 4-week history of cough and fatigue . She has
long-standing hypertension well controlled with atenolol. Her blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to
auscultation. Serum studies show:
Ca
2+ 11.8 mg/dl
Phosphorus 3.4 mg/dl
Globulin 4.8 g/dl
Parathyroid hormone , intact 7 pg/ml (N=10--65)
Parathyroid hormone-related protein 1.0 pmol/L (N<1.3)
An x-ray of the chest shows several nodules throughout both lung fields. Which of the following is the most appropriate next
step in management?

question_stem:
the most appropriate next
step in management?

choices.text: inhibits RNA synthesis, serving as an anti-neoplastic antibiotic , and is rarely used for the treatment of

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Sarcoidosis is an immune-mediated systemic disease resulting in formation of noncaseating granulomas in a variety of involved organs. It is most common in African American females and is often asymptomatic except for lymphadenopathy, with radiographs potentially demonstrating bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and reticulonodular opacities of bilateral lungs. Granulomatous inflammation can result in autonomous production of 1-alpha-hydroxylase , which converts 25-hydroxy-vitamin D3 to the active form 1,25- dihydroxy-vitamin D3. This granulomatous expression of the enzyme results in an increased production of active vitamin D3, which leads to increased intestinal absorption of calcium, resulting in hypercalcemia. This vitamin D3- dependent hypercalcemia results in physiologic suppression of parathyroid hormone. Glucocorticoids are the first line therapy for sarcoidosis, which are utilized to suppress the granulomatous inflammation characteristic of the disease.

distractor_explanations.A: Calcitriol refers to the active form of 1,25-dihydroxy-vitamin D3, which would worsen this patient's hypercalcemia. Divalproex sodium (Choice B) is used in the treatment of seizures, migraine headaches, and psychiatric disturbances such as bipolar disorder. Gallium nitrate (Choice C) treats symptomatic cancer-associated hypercalcemia through inhibition of osteoclast activity. Plicamycin (Choice E) inhibits RNA synthesis, serving as an anti-neoplastic antibiotic , and is rarely used for the treatment of hypercalcemia. Dialysis (Choice F) is utilized for the removal of excess solutes, toxins, and/or water from patients in emergent settings of acute renal failure or chronic end-stage renal disease. Dialysis may be indicated in cases of severe hypercalcemia, where native renal clearance mechanisms will be insufficient or inappropriately slow.
distractor_explanations.G: Parathyroidectomy is indicated for the treatment of hypercalcemia caused by primary hyperparathyroidism . ,. "' , r-- r ,,, Exam Section : Item 22 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
22. A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of shortness of breath on exertion over the past 2 weeks. His last
examination was 38 years ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years . His temperature is 36.?°C (98°F),
pulse is 72/min , respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg. Jugular venous pressure is not increased.
Crackles are heard at both lung bases. Cardiac examination shows an S gallop . Pulses are symmetric without bruits.
4
There is no peripheral edema . His fasting serum glucose concentration is 130 mg/dL , and fasting serum cholesterol
concentration is 270 mg/dl. An x-ray of the chest shows mild cardiomegaly and Kerley B lines. An ECG shows left
ventricular hypertrophy. Echocardiography shows a thickened left ventricle and an ejection fraction of 40% without
segmental wall abnormalities . Which of the following is most likely to have prevented the echocardiographic findings?

question_stem: most likely to have prevented the echocardiographic findings?

choices.text: Adequate control of serum glucose concentrations

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Hypertension is a common cause of chronic systolic and diastolic left-sided heart failure and is considered a modifiable risk factor. This patient's history, signs, symptoms, and exam findings are consistent with chronic left-sided heart failure. Given the lack of an elevated jugular venous pulse, it is unlikely the patient has developed right-sided heart failure. On echocardiography, the patient has a reduced ejection fraction, indicative of systolic heart failure. On physical exam, there is an S gallop with evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy on 4 electrocardiogram , which indicates diastolic heart failure. Additionally, his chest x-ray demonstrates evidence of pulmonary edema (eg, Kerley B lines), a consequence of left-sided heart failure. Adequate control of blood pressure decreases afterload and reduces the degree of cardiac myocyte hypertrophy, which decreases the risk of developing heart failure .

distractor_explanations.B: Adequate control of serum glucose reduces the risk of microvascular complications of diabetes mellitus, such as retinopathy, nephropathy, and neuropathy. Evidence for tight glucose control as a means of significantly reducing macrovascular complications from diabetes mellitus is less clear. Beta-adrenergic agonist therapy (Choice C) is the appropriate treatment for obstructive lung disease such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease or moderate persistent asthma. Low-cholesterol diet (Choice D) would assist in the treatment of hypercholesterolemia, a modifiable risk factor, reducing the likelihood of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. This would reduce his risk for coronary artery disease, with a less direct impact on his risk for developing chronic heart failure . Smoking cessation (Choice E) is a modifiable risk factor in the reduction of cardiovascular and pulmonary disease, although uncontrolled hypertension imparts greater relative risk in this case. ,. "' , r-- r ,,, Exam Section : Item 23 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment aVR V1 V4 II aV L V2 V5 •r1HlllllHllll ff llllllrn11~ Ill a V F V3 V6 llf ltf I[ I I I I1 11 IUI 11111 1111 tlJ IW l Lead V 1 continuous

vignette.presentation:
23. A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after the onset of severe chest pressure and nausea . He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications . He has smoked three packs of
cigarettes daily for 20 years . He is employed as a truck driver and has a sedentary lifestyle . He appears anxious and diaphoretic . He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 107 kg (235 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m 2 His pulse is 44/min
•
and regular , and blood pressure is 160/94 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities . Peripheral pulses are normal. An ECG is shown . Which of the following is the most likely cardiac rhythm?

question_stem: the most likely cardiac rhythm?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Complete heart block is characterized on an ECG by complete dissociation of P waves from the QRS complex. This ECG shows an inferior ST-elevation myocardial infarction. The inferior wall of the heart and the atrioventricular (AV) node often share a common blood supply from the right coronary artery (RCA). When the RCA is blocked, infarction of both the inferior wall and the AV node can occur, which can lead to an AV block with a junctional escape rhythm. In normal sinus rhythm, there is a one-to-one relationship between the P wave and QRS complex, which is not seen in the setting of complete heart block. In fact, there is no relationship between the P and QRS frequencies, with each maintaining its own unique, separate rate per minute. This ECG shows an escape rhythm; the R-R interval is constant and the QRS complex is narrow suggesting a pacer focus located in the common bundle or just distal to the AV node within the His-Purkinje system.

vignette.presentation:
24. A previously healthy 25-year-old graduate student comes to the physician because of numbness of her left leg, stiffness of
her right leg, and urinary urgency. Examination shows increased tone and deep tendon reflexes in the right lower extremity.
Babinski sign is present on the right. Sensation to pinprick is decreased over the left lower extremity and below the level of
T9 on the left. Sensation to vibration and proprioception is intact. Gait testing shows stiffness and circumduction of the right
lower extremity . This patient is most likely to have a lesion at which of the following locations?

question_stem: most likely to have a lesion at which of the following locations?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: A lesion within the spinal cord can result in injury to a single or multiple spinal cord tracts. This can lead to asymmetric physical exam findings depending on the location of the lesion. Fine touch (pinprick) and temperature are transmitted by the anterolateral spinothalamic (ALS) tract. Motor function is carried along the lateral corticospinal tract (CST). Sensation of vibration and proprioception are transmitted along the dorsal columns-medial lemniscus pathway (DC-ML). A lesion located within the anterior and lateral fascicles of the spinal cord white matter would result in injury to the ALS tract and lateral CST. This would result in contralateral loss of fine touch and temperature perception since the primary sensory neuron for the ALS tract decussates within the spinal cord along the ventral white commissure, followed by ascent within the anterolateral tract of the spinal cord. Additionally, there would be findings of ipsilateral motor weakness as motor decussation occurs in the brain stem. With injury to the lateral CST, the patient would manifest upper motoneuron exam findings such as spasticity, hyperreflexia, and Babinski sign.

distractor_explanations.A: Lesions within the brain stem typically result in ipsilateral loss of cranial nerve function (variable depending on the location within the brain stem) and contralateral loss of long-tract spinal cord function (ie, CST, ALS , or DC-ML) . For example, a lesion within the lateral medulla results in Wallenberg syndrome , manifesting with ipsilateral loss of sensation to the face and contralateral body, along with additional cranial nerve symptomatology such as dysphagia, hoarseness, and decreased gag reflex . A lesion within the cerebral hemisphere (Choice B) would result in a contralateral focal neurologic deficit dependent on the location of the lesion. Lesions within the cerebral hemisphere do not result in bilateral asymmetric neurologic exam findings. Peripheral nerve lesions (Choice C) result in symptoms (lower motoneuron weakness, paresthesias, and numbness) within a specific dermatome or peripheral nerve distribution (eg, radial nerve). Conversion reaction (Choice E), also referred to as functional neurologic symptom disorder, can result in loss of motor or sensory function that cannot be explained by a physical illness or injury. Patients are often aware of the symptoms but indifferent about their significance ("/a belle indifference'). ,. "' , r-- r ,,, Exam Section : Item 25 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
25. A 38-year-old African American man with accelerated hypertension is admitted to the hospital. His blood pressure is
230/130 mm Hg and he has grade 111 retinopathy. Serum creatinine concentration is 3. 7 mg/dl. Antihypertensive therapy is
begun. Twenty-four hours later he develops oliguria, and 5 days later his serum creatinine concentration increases to
6.8 mg/dl. He has substernal chest pain and a pericardia! friction rub. Which of the following is the most likely underlying
cause of the pericardia! disease?

question_stem:
the most likely underlying
cause of the pericardia! disease?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Uremia can present with nausea, asterixis, encephalopathy, platelet dysfunction, and pericarditis. This patient's presentation is consistent with uremic pericarditis in the setting of acute renal failure, as a result of uncontrolled hypertension. Accelerated hypertension (now known as hypertensive emergency) is defined as an abrupt, significant increase in blood pressure resulting in end-organ damage. The brain, retina, heart, vasculature, and kidneys are commonly affected , in this case reflected by vision changes in the setting of acute hypertension. Acutely increased blood pressure can result in end-organ damage to the kidney secondary to glomerular and arteriolar injury, which can sometimes be worsened by abrupt antihypertensive therapy. If severe enough, oliguria with an associated rise in serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen can result, leading to symptoms and signs of uremia.

distractor_explanations.A: Collagen vascular disease relates to systemic genetic and autoimmune connective tissue diseases such as Alport syndrome, systemic sclerosis, systemic lupus erythematosus, Marfan syndrome, or Ehlers Danlos syndrome . All of these conditions would be expected to present with a different constellation of symptoms, some of which have the potential for acute renal failure, but typically this is superimposed on the chronic disease state. Pericarditis related to an infection is common, although this patient demonstrates neither signs of infection nor preceding history (eg, fever, viral prodrome) making pyogenic infection (Choice B), tuberculosis (Choice C), and viral infection (Choice E) unlikely, especially given the temporal relation of the patient's accelerated hypertension to renal failure and pericarditis. ,. "' , r-- r ,,, Exam Section : Item 26 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
26. A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine follow-up examination. She has mild, intermittent asthma treated
with an albuterol inhaler as needed . During the past 3 weeks, she has had three to four weekly episodes of shortness of
breath and wheezing that resolve with use of the inhaler. She has never required intubation for asthma . She is otherwise
asymptomatic . She has no other history of serious illness and takes no other medications . There are no known sick
contacts . Her temperature is 36 .?°C (98°F) , pulse is 88/min , respirations are 16/min , and blood pressure is 118/64 mm Hg.
Wheezes are heard bilaterally. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most appropriate
next step in pharmacotherapy?

question_stem:
the most appropriate
next step in pharmacotherapy?

choices.text: Increase the dosage of albuterol to four times daily

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Asthma is characterized by reversible obstruction of the bronchi secondary to hyperreactivity and airway inflammation . Patients present with episodes of wheezing, dry cough, and dyspnea . On physical examination, wheezes are heard, and there is sometimes a component of prolonged expiration relative to inspiration. Chest radiographs are typically normal. Pulmonary function tests may be normal between symptomatic exacerbations but during such episodes demonstrate an obstructive pattern with increased residual volume and total lung capacity. The severity of asthma is graded based on frequency of day- and night-time symptomatic episodes. Intermittent asthma is characterized as symptoms occurring S2 days per week and S2 nights per month and requires as needed short-acting bronchodilators for symptomatic relief. Individuals with mild persistent asthma (such as this patient) exhibit symptoms >2 days per week or >2 nights per month, which requires the addition of daily low-dose inhaled corticosteroids (eg, fluticasone). Moderate persistent asthma is treated with the addition of long-acting inhaled beta-2 agonists (eg, salmeterol) to the regimen of low-dose inhaled corticosteroids and as-needed short acting bronchodilator. Severe persistent asthma is treated with the addition of high-dose corticosteroids to the regimen.

distractor_explanations.A: Albuterol inhalers act as stand-alone treatment for intermittent asthma to assist in shortening symptomatic exacerbations. While albuterol plays a role in the management of all types of asthma, her asthma is mild persistent and requires the addition of a steroid. Salmeterol (Choice C) is a long-acting beta-2 agonist, used in treatment of moderate persistent asthma, working in conjunction with low-dose inhaled corticosteroids. Theophylline (Choice D) results in bronchodilation through the inhibition of phosphodiesterase. It has a narrow therapeutic window, resulting in significant cardiotoxicity and neurotoxicity. It is a late and/or last-line treatment. Tiotropium (Choice E) is a long-acting anti-muscarinic agent resulting in bronchodilation, which is indicated for use in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease . ,. "' , r-- r ,,, Exam Section : Item 27 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
27. During transfusion of a second unit of crossmatched packed red blood cells for lower gastrointestinal bleeding , a
67-year-old woman has the onset of fever and chills. Six months ago, she had gastrointestinal bleeding and had no
complications after transfusion of 3 units of crossmatched packed red blood cells. She appears anxious . Her temperature is
39.2°C (102.6°F), pulse is 105/min , respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg. Examination of the skin
shows no abnormalities . The lungs are clear to auscultation . Serum studies of a post-transfusion sample show no free
hemoglobin. A direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test is negative . The ABO blood groups of the patient and donor are verified ,
and a second crossmatch reconfirms compatibility . In addition to intravenous administration of crystalloid solution, which of
the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

question_stem: the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Acute febrile transfusion reactions occur during the administration of blood transfusions secondary to preformed cytokines in the transfused blood. This reaction is not related to inaccurate cross matching or administration of an incorrect blood type to the patient. It is treated with acetaminophen plus fluids to blunt the hypothalamic response to cytokines. In contrast, hemolytic transfusion reactions would present with a positive Coombs test and free hemoglobin in serum.

distractor_explanations.B: Dantrolene is commonly used to treat malignant hyperthermia, which is characterized by rigidity, hyperthermia, and autonomic instability, often due to anesthetic medications or nitrates . Epinephrine (Choice C) is used to treat anaphylactic transfusion reactions which would be characterized by tachycardia, wheezing, hypotension, angioedema, itching, urticaria, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. Penicillin (Choice D) is an antibiotic used to treat various gram-positive and spirochete infections. In the setting of a fever occurring during a transfusion, the time course is likely too abrupt to reflect a new infection, even if acquired from the blood. Prednisone (Choice E) is used to treat multiple inflammatory, atopic, infectious, and autoimmune conditions . It has no specific role in managing an acute febrile transfusion reaction. ,. "' , r-- ,. , Exam Section : Item 28 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
29. An 87-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of constant , increasing abdominal pain. The
pain is not related to eating. She has had generalized itching for the past week . She underwent a cholecystectomy for
gallstones at the age of 63 years . She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (175 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m 2 Her temperature
•
is 37°C (98.6°F) , pulse is 76/min , and blood pressure is 142/82 mm Hg. Examination shows excoriations on both upper
extremities . Abdominal examination shows mild epigastric tenderness . Results of a complete blood count are within the
reference range. Serum studies show :
Total bilirubin 1.9 mg/dl
Alkaline phosphatase 305 U/L
AST 34 U/L
ALT 42 U/L
Amylase 56 U/L
Abdominal ultrasonography shows dilation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct. The pancreas is poorly visualized
because of overlying bowel gas. Which of the follow ing is the most likely cause of these findings?

question_stem: the most likely cause of these findings?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Pancreatic adenocarcinoma most commonly occurs in the pancreatic head. It is often initially characterized by nonspecific vague abdominal discomfort or weight loss. As the pancreatic mass increases in size, it can lead to the obstruction and dilation of both the common bile duct and main pancreatic duct, referred to as a double-duct sign on ultrasound. This can result in painless jaundice and/or pancreatitis from obstruction of these ducts. If the pancreatic adenocarcinoma continues to spread and results in infiltration of surround ing abdominal viscera and/or encasement of adjacent neurovascular structures, this can manifest with severe abdominal pain. The nonspecific nature of pancreatic adenocarcinoma's early symptoms creates a diagnostic dilemma , as many benign conditions present similarly. It is frequently asymptomatic until it creates an obstruction, gastrointestinal dysfunction, perineural or vascular encasement/invasion, or metastatic disease .

distractor_explanations.A: Choledocholithiasis presents with acute right upper quadrant and epigastric pain, nausea, and vomiting, often following a fatty meal in a patient with either known gallstones or risk factors for them. This patient had a cholecystectomy and while post-cholecystectomy syndromes including ductal stones are possible, they are less likely. Primary biliary cirrhosis (Choice C) results in destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts and classically presents in middle-aged females . It is characterized by jaundice , pruritus, anorexia, and elevated alkaline phosphatase. Sclerosing cholangitis (Choice D) presents either primarily or in patients with a history of ulcerative colitis. It presents as inflammation and chronic fibrosis of the biliary tree resulting in a beaded appearance to the biliary tree with multifocal strictures . Symptoms of sclerosing cholangitis include anorexia, nausea , vomiting, and malabsorption. Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction (Choice E) would result in dilated biliary and pancreatic ducts on imaging; however, this would be transient and not necessarily accompanied by an elevation in alkaline phosphatase or additional symptoms such as pain and itching. ,. "' , r-- r ,,, Exam Section : Item 30 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
30. A 42-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-month history of progressive shortness of breath, cough, and
intermittent wheezing . Her cough usually is nonproductive but occasionally has produced white sputum . She is otherwise
asymptomatic . Nine months ago, she was intubated and mechanically ventilated for 2 weeks for management of
Guillain-Barre syndrome . Her only medication is a daily multivitamin . She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for
20 years. She smokes marijuana two times monthly. She does not drink alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pulse
oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97% . High-pitched , end-expiratory wheezes are heard in the anterior
aspect of the lungs. No crackles are heard. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities . Which of the
following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Tracheomalacia refers to softening and deterioration of the tracheal cartilage, which results in excessive end-expiratory collapse due to atrophy and/or reduction of the tracheal elastic fibers and decreased integrity of tracheal cartilage. In adults, this most commonly occurs after prolonged intubation with an endotracheal tube, which results in damage to the tracheal cartilage directly, and can increase the risk of tracheomalacia. Clinically, this presents with shortness of breath, nonproductive cough, and expiratory stridor. It can also sound like wheezing on lung auscultation.

distractor_explanations.A: with no reported prior history of asthma . Her high-pitched, end-expiratory wheezes and other symptoms are likely secondary to tracheomalacia and its associated expiratory collapse. Guillain-Barre syndrome (Choice B) is typically self limited and affects the lungs through diaphragmatic paralysis, not through an obstructive airway mechanism as seen in this patient. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (Choice C) results in shortness of breath, cough, and fever after exposure to a specific antigen. Paradoxic vocal cord motion (Choice D) occurs when the vocal cords close during breathing, resulting in an obstructed airway. There are many causes of paradoxic vocal cord motion, including exercise, coughing, and acid reflux. ,. "' , r-- r ,,, Exam Section : Item 31 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
32. An otherwise healthy 41-year-old woman comes to the
physician because of a lesion on the calf for 2 months.
A photograph of the lesion is shown . Which of the
following is the most appropriate next step in
management?

question_stem:
the most appropriate next step in
management?

choices.text: would be appropriate for an infectious lesion

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: A nevus of the skin is more likely to be a malignancy such as melanoma when it demonstrates asymmetry, irregular borders, uneven coloring, diameter ~6 mm, and rapid evolution. Appropriate management of a potentially malignant dermatologic lesion consists of excision with negative margins , which is both diagnostic and therapeutic. This is performed either through minimally invasive surgery such as Mohs, or through a wider traditional surgical excision.

distractor_explanations.A: Corticosteroid therapy would be appropriate if this lesion were inflammatory or atopic (eg, eczema) . Antibiotic therapy (Choice B) would be appropriate for an infectious lesion (eg, cellulitis, erysipelas). This lesion is more likely malignant given its concerning features, and these therapies would delay definitive diagnosis and treatment, increasing the risk for distant and lymph node metastases.
distractor_explanations.C: Cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen is indicated for premalignant lesions, such as actinic keratosis, or hyperkeratotic lesions, such as condylomas (warts). Punch biopsy (Choice D) would provide diagnostic information but would not be therapeutic, since a portion of the lesion is left behind, and negative margins would not be confirmed. This lesion shows several concerning features for an aggressive malignancy, which must be diagnosed and treated (Choice F). ,. "' , r-- ,. , Exam Section : Item 33 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
33. A 77-year-old man with dementia , Alzheimer type, is brought to the physician because of a 1-week history of urinary
incontinence . He has had frequent loss of small amounts of urine , especially at night. Abdominal examination shows
tenderness and a 10-cm tender suprapubic mass . He can void spontaneously and has a poor urinary stream . Urinalysis
shows 4 WBC/hpf and 1+ bacteria . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Recurrent infections, as seen in this patient, raise concern for an underlying primary immunodeficiency. Primary immunodeficiencies may result from abnormalities of acquired immunity (B-cell , T-cell), innate immunity, or combined dysfunction. Specifically, a decreased, absent, or aberrant production of immunoglobulin by B-cells can result in recurrent sinopulmonary infections, leading to multiple recurrent sinus infections and pneumonia, which this patient demonstrates . These recurrent pulmonary infections can lead to the development of bronchiectasis over time . For further differentiation of the patient's primary immunodeficiency, quantitative immunoglobulin testing should be performed to delineate the patient's immunologic pathophysiology. B-cell disorders include such diseases as X-linked agammaglobulinemia, selective lgA deficiency, and common variable immunodeficiency . Given the patient's age and presentation, common variable immunodeficiency is the most likely etiology since it typically presents in early adulthood and characteristically leads to increased sinopulmonary infections.

distractor_explanations.A: are an invasive form of diagnostic evaluation , necessary if a primary bone marrow pathology is expected such as lymphoproliferative disorders or otherwise unexplained cytopenias. Bronchoalveolar lavage (
distractor_explanations.B: is recommended to definitively identify the infectious organism present in the setting of severe and/or persistent pneumonia. Open lung biopsy (
distractor_explanations.C: may be indicated for a variety of clinical scenarios (eg, interstitial lung disease , pulmonary nodule/mass), but is not necessary for the diagnosis of an immunodeficiency. Sputum culture for acid-fast bacilli (
distractor_explanations.E: most commonly is used to evaluate for a mycobacterial infection. "' , r-- ,. ,,,

vignette.presentation:
34. A 57-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine examination. He feels well. He has rheumatoid arthritis, type 2
diabetes mellitus , hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include methotrexate , metformin , lisinopril ,
simvastatin, and 81-mg aspirin. He drinks one to two glasses of wine each evening . His temperature is 37.2°C (98 .9°F),
pulse is 88/min, respirations are 16/min , and blood pressure is 138/78 mm Hg. Examination shows an abdominal bruit.
Laboratory studies show:
Serum
Na+
142 mEq/L
K+
3.5 mEq/L
cI
120 mEq/L
Hco3-
10 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 22 mg/dL
Glucose 134 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Urine pH 6.5
Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?

question_stem: the most likely explanation for these findings?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Renal tubular acidosis (RTA) results in a hyperchloremic, non-anion gap metabolic acidosis from dysregulation of the renal tubules. There are three types of RTA, varying in etiology and pathophysiology , but all resulting in a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis. This patient demonstrates a low bicarbonate level , with a normal anion gap of 12, consistent with a non-anion gap acidosis. Distal RTA (type 1) results from a defect in renal secretion of W, which results in the lack of generation of HCO ultimately leading to a metabolic acidosis. It is -, 3 characterized by a urine pH >5.5. The most common causes of type 1 RTA include analgesic nephropathy, congenital obstructive urinary tract anomalies , drugs (eg , amphotericin), and autoimmune diseases resulting in hypergammaglobulinemia (eg, rheumatoid arthritis, Sjogren).

distractor_explanations.A: Alcohol use does not independently alter acid-base pathology outside of extremes such as alcoholic ketoacidosis or consumption of volatile alcohols that are metabolized to organic acids such as methanol and ethylene glycol. Diabetic ketoacidosis (Choice B) typically occurs in patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus as a result of increased insulin requirements during times of physiologic stress (eg, infection) or insulin nonadherence. Diabetic ketoacidosis results in a metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap. Increased lactate production (Choice C) can result from any hypoperfusion state, deficiency in the TCA cycle, impaired oxidative phosphorylation, or from vitamin deficiencies (eg, thiamine), and is associated with an increased anion gap metabolic acidosis. Salicylate intoxication (Choice E) initially results in the development of respiratory alkalosis from hyperventilation with a delayed anion gap metabolic acidosis . ,. "' , r-- r ,,, Exam Section : Item 35 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
35. A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of difficulty swallowing for 6 days. He says that food becomes stuck in
his throat. Over the past 2 weeks, he has had low-grade fever and fatigue . He has had an 11-kg (25-lb) weight loss over the
past year. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He uses intravenous heroin. His temperature is
37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 110/78 mm Hg. Examination shows anterior and posterior cervical
lymphadenopathy . There are thick white plaques over the buccal mucosa and soft palate . The lungs are clear to
auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's dysphagia?

question_stem: the most likely cause of this patient's dysphagia?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Dysphagia has many structural, malignant, neurologic, infectious, and inflammatory causes. In the setting of weight loss, fatigue, low-grade fever, and intravenous drug abuse, the white oropharyngeal plaques are consistent with esophagitis from Candida species as a cause of dysphagia, a common opportunistic infection in an immunocompromised host such as a person with HIV. The patient's cervical lymphadenopathy is likely reactive to the adjacent esophageal infectious process. Herpes simplex virus and cytomegalovirus are also common infectious etiologies of esophagitis in this population, but these typically present with esophageal ulcers.

distractor_explanations.A: Bacterial endocarditis presents classically with fevers, a new heart murmur, evidence of disseminated infection such as septic emboli, and vascular/immunologic phenomena such as Janeway lesions, Osler nodes, Roth spots, and splinter hemorrhages. Esophageal cancer with nodal metastases (Choice B) could explain the patient's dysphagia, weight loss, and vague systemic symptoms, however, would not classically present with white oropharyngeal plaques, but rather esophageal narrowing with irregular borders from an infiltrative neoplastic mass. Oral cancer with nodal metastases (Choice D) could present with a white oral plaque (eg, squamous cell carcinoma); however, this would typically be a solitary plaque as opposed to multiple, thick plaques. Tertiary syphilis (Choice E) would not be expected to present with multiple white oral plaques; it classically presents with neurologic symptoms, gummas, and aortitis. ,. "' , r-- ,. , Exam Section : Item 36 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
36. A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 6-hour history of shortness of breath and
nonproductive cough . She has had similar episodes, which typically last 18 hours, two to three times weekly during the past
3 months. She is asymptomatic when she runs outside for 45 minutes, five times weekly . She has not had chest pain. She
has no history of serious illness, and her only medication is an oral contraceptive . She does not smoke cigarettes. She
smokes marijuana once monthly. She moved to a new apartment building 4 months ago and she often uses the communal
pool and hot tub. She appears to be in mild respiratory distress. Her temperature is 37 .9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 115/min,
respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of
93% . She is not using accessory muscles of respiration. Diffuse, fine crackles are heard prominently at the lung bases ; no
wheezes are heard . The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely
cause of this patient's symptoms?

question_stem:
the most likely
cause of this patient's symptoms?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis represents a mixed type Ill and IV hypersensitivity reaction to various environmental antigens. This typically results in episodic dyspnea, fever, and cough which starts a few hours after the exposure to the antigen. Classically, this occurs in farmers and individuals exposed to bird droppings. It can also occur secondary to the use of hot tubs and resultant antigen exposure, as seen in this patient. Similarly, her symptoms may also represent a chemical pneumonitis or bronchitis from inhaled chlorine. Treatment requires avoidance of the specific inciting antigen. If chronic exposure occurs, this can result in alveolar thickening, noncaseating granuloma formation, and possible upper lobe predominant pulmonary fibrosis.

distractor_explanations.C: Illicit drug use may result in various degrees of shortness of breath depending on the agent and mode of use. Marijuana, when smoked, can result in tracheobronchial inflammation and/or pneumonitis, although she only smokes once monthly, which does not correlate with the frequency of her symptoms. Swimming pool use (Choice D) is not directly associated with hypersensitivity pneumonitis, though could be associated with a chemical pneumonitis from chlorine. The type of exercise (Choice E) may have an impact on a patient's asthma symptoms, although would not play a role in hypersensitivity pneumonitis. ,. "' , r-- r ,,, Exam Section : Item 37 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
37. A 32-year-old homeless man is admitted to the hospital and placed in respiratory isolation because of a
2-week history of fever, chills, and cough productive of blood-tinged sputum. He also has had shortness
of breath after walking approximately 100 feet. He has had a 13.6-kg (30-lb) weight loss during the past
6 months. He takes no prescription medications but has a history of intravenous drug use. He is
168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 45 kg (100 lb); BMI is 16 kg/m 2 His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1 °F),
•
pulse is 102/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 102/68 mm Hg. He is using accessory
muscles of respiration. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 90%. Examination
shows shotty cervical lymphadenopathy. There is bilateral wasting of the temporal and supraclavicular
muscles . Diffuse crackles are heard throughout both lung fields. His leukocyte count is 11,500/mm 3
(70% segmented neutrophils, 1% eosinophils, 1% basophils, 25% lymphocytes, and 3% monocytes) . A
PPD skin test is negative. A chest x-ray is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Pulmonary tuberculosis can present in various stages. Primary tuberculosis results from an initial exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis, leading to the development of hilar lymphadenopathy and a Ghon focus (Ghon complex). Reactivation tuberculosis (secondary) typically results in apical pulmonary opacity with fibrocaseous cavitary lesions. This may present clinically with prolonged fever, night sweats, weight loss (including skeletal muscle wasting), and hemoptysis. A PPD skin test can be negative in the setting of tuberculosis infection if the patient is immunocompromised. Reactivation tuberculosis requires combination anti-microbial treatment including rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol, along with initial respiratory isolation.

distractor_explanations.A: Aspiration pneumonia occurs in patients at risk for aspiration (eg, elderly, stroke, dementia). It commonly presents with cough and fever following an aspiration episode, with consolidation most commonly occurring in the dependent portions of the right middle or lower lobes. Bronchiectasis (Choice B) refers to chronic dilation of the bronchi and/or bronchioles as a result of chronic necrotizing infection, most commonly related to chronic bronchial obstruction, cystic fibrosis, Kartagener syndrome, and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis. Sarcoidosis (Choice C) is a chronic non-caseating granulomatous systemic inflammatory condition, which most commonly affects the hilar lymph nodes and lungs . Pulmonary sarcoidosis can result in coarse reticular pulmonary opacities, which may progress to a restrictive lung disease from interstitial fibrosis, although acute fever and hemoptysis would be rare. Septic pulmonary emboli (Choice D) typically occur in the setting of endocarditis (eg, tricuspid valve) or infected sources of thromboemboli (eg, Lemierre syndrome) . Wegener granulomatosis (Choice F) can result in multifocal cavitary pulmonary nodules, but typically also occurs in the setting of upper respiratory tract symptoms (eg , perforated nasal septum, chronic sinusitis) and glomerulonephritis (eg, hematuria). r , ,. ' , F' Exam Section : Item 38 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
38. A47-year-old woman comes to the physician for a health maintenance examination . She has mild hyperparathyroidism that
does not require treatment. She takes no medications. She does not exercise or eat meat or dairy products . She is
163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 104 kg (230 lb); BMI is 40 kg/m 2 Examination shows no abnormalities . Which of the
•
following is the strongest predisposing factor for osteoarthritis in this patient during the next 10 years?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Recurrent infections, as seen in this patient, raise concern for an underlying primary immunodeficiency. Primary immunodeficiencies may result from abnormalities of acquired immunity (B-cell , T-cell), innate immunity, or combined dysfunction. Specifically, a decreased, absent, or aberrant production of immunoglobulin by B-cells can result in recurrent sinopulmonary infections, leading to multiple recurrent sinus infections and pneumonia, which this patient demonstrates . These recurrent pulmonary infections can lead to the development of bronchiectasis over time . For further differentiation of the patient's primary immunodeficiency, quantitative immunoglobulin testing should be performed to delineate the patient's immunologic pathophysiology. B-cell disorders include such diseases as X-linked agammaglobulinemia, selective lgA deficiency, and common variable immunodeficiency . Given the patient's age and presentation, common variable immunodeficiency is the most likely etiology since it typically presents in early adulthood and characteristically leads to increased sinopulmonary infections.

distractor_explanations.A: are an invasive form of diagnostic evaluation , necessary if a primary bone marrow pathology is expected such as lymphoproliferative disorders or otherwise unexplained cytopenias. Bronchoalveolar lavage (
distractor_explanations.B: is recommended to definitively identify the infectious organism present in the setting of severe and/or persistent pneumonia. Open lung biopsy (
distractor_explanations.C: may be indicated for a variety of clinical scenarios (eg, interstitial lung disease , pulmonary nodule/mass), but is not necessary for the diagnosis of an immunodeficiency. Sputum culture for acid-fast bacilli (
distractor_explanations.E: most commonly is used to evaluate for a mycobacterial infection. "' , r-- ,. ,,,

vignette.presentation:
39. A 4 7-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for treatment of alcoholic pancreatitis . He is currently receiving intravenous 0.9% saline ,
intravenous morphine , oral lorazepam for alcohol withdrawal , and multiple vitamins. He has no known allergies . He has smoked one pack of
cigarettes daily for 25 years. He drinks one fifth of vodka daily. He frequently has sexual intercourse with prostitutes . On examination , he is
diaphoretic . His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 88/min , respirations are 18/min , and blood pressure is 150/84 mm Hg. Examination
shows no lymphadenopathy . The abdomen is distended with epigastric tenderness . A photograph of the genitalia is shown . There is a lesion
under the prepuce . The lesions over the penile shaft are tender , but the lesion over the glans penis is nontender . Serum rapid plasma reagin is
negative . Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for the lesion on this patient's glans penis?

question_stem: the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for the lesion on this patient's glans penis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Syphilis is a sexually transmitted disease from the spirochete Treponema pallidum that can present in multiple stages. Primarily syphilis presents with a painless chancre (ulcer) of the genitalia. There are typically no systemic signs or symptoms of syphilis infection at this stage. Rapid plasma reagin can be falsely negative in the primary stage of syphilis . Dark-field microscopy of fluid from the chancre is the most sensitive test for diagnosis of primary syphilis . The treatment for primary syphilis is a single benzathine Penicillin G intramuscular injection.

distractor_explanations.A: Acyclovir is a guanosine analog used for the treatment of herpes simplex virus or varicella zoster virus. Azithromycin (Choice B) is a macrolide antibiotic commonly used for atypical pneumonia, chlamydia! sexually transmitted infections, and Bordetel/a pertussis infection . Ciprofloxacin (Choice C) is a fluoroquinolone used for treatment of urinary and gastrointestinal tract infections from gram-negative rods. Doxycycline (Choice D) is a tetracycline antibiotic effective against a number of gram-negative and gram-positive bacteria, including methicillin-resistant S. aureus, Borrelia, Rickettsia, and Chlamydia. r , ,. "' , F' Exam Section : Item 40 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment 40 . A 77-year-old man with alcoholism is brought to the emergency department after his landlord found him unconscious in his apartment on a hot summer day. No history is available. On arrival , he is obtunded but is responsive to painful stimuli. His temperature is 40°C (104°F) , pulse is 120/min , respirations are 20/min , and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Examination shows warm , dry skin and dry mucous membranes . The pupils are equally round and reactive to light ; ocular movements are intact. The neck is supple . No evidence of trauma is noted. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings . Laboratory studies show : Hematocrit 33% Leukocyte count 13,500/mm 3 Platelet count 75,000/mm 3 Prothrombin time 13 sec Partial thromboplastin time 50 sec Serum Na+ 149 mEq/L Cl· 110 mEq/L K+ 5.4 mEq/L HC0 20 mEq/L 3 Urea nitrogen 60 mg/dL Glucose 50 mg/dL Creatinine 3.5 mg/dL Bilirubin (total) 4 mg/dL AST 150 U/L Creatine kinase 550 U/L Blood alcohol 0 mg/dL Urinalysis Blood 2+ Protein 1+ WBC 1-2/hpf RBC 1-2/hpf Casts few granular An x-ray of the chest and CT scan of the head show no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A) Delirium tremens B Heat stroke 1 C) Neuroleptic malignant syndrome D) Subarachnoid hemorrhage E) Thyroid storm F) Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome Correct Answer: B. Heat stroke is characterized by hyperthermia, altered mental status or neurologic deficits, and variable physical signs and symptoms depending on severity. In this case, this patient was found down, in a hot apartment, presumably from the combined effects of alcohol intoxication and subsequent overheating from the environment. His exam shows tachycardia, hypotension, and warm, flushed skin. His workup reveals hypernatremia, hyperchloremia, hyperkalemia, elevated creatinine, elevated blood urea nitrogen, and elevated creatine kinase. This constellation of findings reflects hyperthermia, severe hypovolemia, rhabdomyolysis, and acute renal failure. Incorrect Answers: A, C, D, E, and F. Delirium tremens {Choice A) occurs 48-72 hours following cessation of alcohol use in a patient with alcoholism and is characterized by delirium, hallucinations, and autonomic instability. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome {Choice C) occurs secondary to certain classes of medications, such as antipsychotics, and is characterized by hyperthermia, muscle rigidity, and autonomic instability. Subarachnoid hemorrhage {Choice D) typically presents with an acute-onset, severe headache, and is shown on imaging as hyperdense material {blood) within the subarachnoid space. Thyroid storm {Choice E) presents with hyperthermia, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, diaphoresis, agitation, tremor, nausea, diarrhea, and weight loss, and may progress to high-output heart failure, obtundation, seizure, or coma. It typically occurs in a patient with a known diagnosis of hyperthyroidism following a secondary insult such as infection or physiologic stress from surgery or trauma. Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome {Choice F) occurs secondary to thiamine deficiency and is characterized by neurologic symptoms, including confusion, nystagmus, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia, followed by dementia and psychosis. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 41 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment 41 . A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of swelling of his left hand and redness of his left forearm , wrist , and hand after being involved in a grease fire while working at a restaurant yesterday. After emptying the fryers , a small amount of grease splattered and left small burns on his arms . He does not take any medications. He has a history of "abnormal liver tests" and condylomata acuminata . He has had multiple sexual partners during the past 10 years and does not use condoms . His temperature is 38.8°C (101 .9°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 138/68 mm Hg. A photograph of the left upper extremity is shown . There is no crepitus or fluctuance . Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities . Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 18,000/mm 3 with a left shift . X-rays of the left hand show diffuse soft-tissue edema . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A) Brown recluse spider bite B) Disseminated gonococcal infection C) Erysipelas D) Fasciitis E) Gout F) LymRhangitis G) Sporotrichosis Correct Answer: F. Lymphangitis refers to inflammation or infection of the lymphatic channels, which often occurs secondary to an infectious source at a location distal to the lymphatic channel, in this case correlating with the location of the patient's burns. The most common cause of lymphangitis is Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A), with Sporothrix schenckii representing the most common fungal lymphangitis. Clinically, it presents with erythema in a linear, longitudinal band appearance, which correlates with the associated lymphatic drainage channel. There is also typically painful lymphadenopathy along the associated lymphatic drainage channel. This can result in pain and swelling with the possibility for high fevers. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, E, and G. Brown recluse spider bites {Choice A) are associated with dermatonecrosis due to cytotoxic venom. Systemic illness is possible, more common in children, elderly, and chronically ill individuals, which can manifest with fever, rashes, and myalgias, and rarely, disseminated intravascular coagulation and end-organ damage. Disseminated gonococcal infection {Choice B) presents with pustular skin lesions, migratory polyarthralgia, and tenosynovitis. Erysipelas {Choice C) results from infection of the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics, most commonly from S. pyogenes, and on exam appears as a well-defined region of raised induration and erythema. Fasciitis {Choice D) refers to infection spreading along a deep fascial plane, most commonly from mixed flora (anaerobic and aerobic bacteria). It typically presents with acute onset of pain, which progresses to anesthesia, at a site of prior trauma or surgery. Evidence of gas production (crepitus), bullae, and severe pain out of proportion to the physical exam are indications of a necrotizing infection. Gout {Choice E) refers to monosodium urate crystals resulting in inflammatory monoarticular arthritis, classically the first metatarsophalangeal joint. Joint fluid analysis shows needle-shaped, negatively birefringent crystals, with the possibility for erosive changes of underlying cortical bone. Sporotrichosis {Choice G) results from infection by Sporothrix schenckii, a fungus, which grows within the rosettes of conidia plants and is typically introduced through traumatic breakage of the skin (eg, thorn). This results in a local pustule and ulcer formation, with an ascending lymphangitis. The patient's injury was not secondary to injury from vegetation, limiting the likelihood of sporotrichosis as the causative agent for the lymphangitis. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 42 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
42. A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has a
3-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin and lisinopril. Her pulse
is 68/min , and blood pressure is 116/74 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a
hemoglobin A of 6.4% , serum creatinine concentration of 0.7 mg/dl , and serum LDL-cholesterol concentration of
c
1
112 mg/dl. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in pharmacotherapy?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in pharmacotherapy?

choices.text: Add rosiglitazone to her current regimen
Add simvastatin to her current regimen
No change in therapy is indicated

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Simvastatin is a lipid-lowering agent that primarily reduces LDL in patients with hypercholesterolemia through the inhibition of hydroxymethylglutaryl-CoA reductase. While recommendations for lipid levels vary by recommending organization, general recommendations for individuals with diabetes mellitus center around a target LDL <100 mg/dl, HDL >40 mg/dl, and triglycerides <150 mg/dl. Patients with diabetes mellitus exhibit a higher incidence of cardiovascular disease, with increased morbidity and mortality secondary to macrovascular complications such as myocardial infarction, peripheral arterial disease, and stroke. It is critical to implement lipid-lowering agents to achieve target ranges for lipoprotein levels. Treatment of LDL cholesterol levels is considered the first priority for pharmacologic therapy. Statins are the first-line treatment medication for the improvement of dyslipidemia in the setting of diabetes mellitus.

distractor_explanations.A: Rosiglitazone is an oral hypoglycemic drug which binds to PPAR-gamma nuclear transcription factor to increase insulin sensitivity. Metformin (Choice D) is an oral biguanide hypoglycemic agent that serves as the first-line oral treatment for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Neither oral hypoglycemic medication is indicated in this patient with appropriate HbA 1c values. Lisinopril (Choice C) inhibits angiotensin converting enzyme, which can be utilized for hypertension management, prevention of diabetic nephropathy, and to decrease mortality in the setting of heart failure management. This patient's LDL level is currently suboptimal, requiring initiation of simvastatin (Choice E). ,. "' , r-- r ,,, Exam Section : Item 43 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
43. A previously healthy 72-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of episodic
memory loss, dizziness, and double vision and a 2-hour history of burning pain in his left great toe . During the past
2 months, he has had a moderate itching sensation over his legs. On arrival, he is conscious and oriented to person , place ,
and time. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 75/min and regular, and blood pressure is 170/80 mm Hg.
Examination shows bluish-red discoloration of the left great toe. There is no pain on movement of the toe . On cardiac
examination, no murmurs or gallops are heard. The spleen tip is palpated 3 cm below the left costal margin . Neurologic
examination shows no focal findings. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 18.5 g/dL
Hematocrit 62%
Leukocyte count 13,000/mm3
Platelet count 420,000/mm3
Serum
Urea nitrogen 22 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Ferritin 14 ng/mL
Uric acid 12.9 mg/dL
Which of the following interventions will most rapidly correct this patient's visual and memory disturbances?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Polycythemia vera is a chronic myeloproliferative disorder resulting in disordered, increased production of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets secondary to a JAK2 mutation . It often presents with increased pruritus, especially after hot showers secondary to increased mast cell production. Additionally, it can result in episodic severe, burning pain with red-blue discoloration secondary to blood clot formation in extremity vessels , referred to as erythromelalgia. The marked increase in red blood cell production and hematocrit can lead to the development of hyperviscosity syndrome , which presents with blurred vision and central nervous system symptoms related to vascular congestion . Therapeutic phlebotomy results in decreased red blood cell mass and blood volume, which would be the best initial treatment for reversal of the patient's symptoms.

distractor_explanations.A: Aspirin irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase enzymes 1 and 2 resulting in decreased platelet aggregation but has no effect on red blood cell mass and blood volume. Heparin (Choice B) inhibits various clotting factors including thrombin and factor Xa after binding to antithrombin 111, resulting in immediate anticoagulation, although not affecting red blood cell mass or concentration. Hydroxyurea (Choice C) inhibits ribonucleotide reductase and is used primarily for the treatment of sickle cell disease. Infusion of 0.9% saline (Choice D) would result in decreased red blood cell concentration (hematocrit), although would further increase blood volume. ,. "' , r-- ,. , Exam Section : Item 44 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
44. A previously healthy 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of low-grade fever, fatigue,
and intermittent diarrhea. She has had one episode of blood in her stool and a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss during this time .
She takes no medications . Her father has hypertension , and her older sister has irritable bowel syndrome . The patient does
not smoke. She drinks one to two glasses of wine monthly. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.2°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations
are 20/min, and blood pressure is 102/60 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness and no rebound ; bowel
sounds are increased . Rectal examination shows normal sphincter tone. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive . Which
of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Inflammatory bowel disease comprises both Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis. Crohn disease is characterized by transmural inflammation that can involve any portion of the gastrointestinal tract, manifesting with skip lesions. It particularly involves the terminal ileum and typically spares the rectum. Clinically, it can present with chronic abdominal pain, low-grade fever, weight loss, and watery or bloody diarrhea. Physical exam findings of Crohn disease include perianal fissures/fistulas, abdominal tenderness, and possible positive fecal occult blood, although bloody stools are not required for the diagnosis. Colonoscopy can demonstrate aphthous or linear ulcers with luminal strictures, inflammatory lesions, and a cobblestone mucosa. Biopsy is required for definitive diagnosis.

distractor_explanations.A: Celiac disease is a gluten-sensitive enteropathy resulting from autoimmune-mediated intolerance of gliadin. This results in inflammatory damage to the small bowel mucosa that primarily affects the distal duodenum and/or proximal jejunum, which leads to decreased mucosal absorption. Cytomegalovirus colitis (Choice C) occurs in patients with immunodeficiency, most commonly AIDS, and typically presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, rectal bleeding, and fever, often superimposed on the patient's primary condition. Giardiasis (Choice D) presents with foul-smelling, fatty diarrhea and bloating, typically in campers who ingest cysts from standing freshwater. Irritable bowel syndrome (Choice E) presents with recurrent abdominal pain, which improves with defecation, along with a change in frequency and consistency of stool. ,. "' , r-- r ,,, Exam Section : Item 45 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
45. A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of a rash over her left wrist. She first noticed the
rash after she started wearing a new watch , but the rash has not resolved since she stopped wearing the watch 3 days ago.
She has a 2-year history of hypertension treated with atenolol. She is wearing perfume today. Examination of the left wrist
shows erythematous papules . There are several nevi over the chest and abdomen . The skin is diffusely dry and flakes
easily. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

question_stem: the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Contact dermatitis is a type IV T cell-mediated hypersensitivity reaction following exposure to an allergen, which results in the development of a pruritic, erythematous, and papular rash. It is characteristically distributed along the location of clothing, perfume, plant contact, or nickel jewelry contact. The rashes are often described as linear or angular in shape. In some cases, the rash can spread from the point of initial contact through transfer of the allergen by hand contact. Frequent allergens resulting in contact dermatitis are nickel, topical antibiotics, and poison ivy or oak . Diagnosis for the specific causative allergen can be made through patch testing, with first-line treatments being topical corticosteroids and avoidance of the culprit allergen.

distractor_explanations.A: Atenolol is a beta-1 selective antagonist, used in the management of hypertension and supraventricular dysrhythmias. Side effects of atenolol include bradycardia and atrioventricular block. While perfume (Choice B) can result in a type IV hypersensitivity reaction, the patient's rash is located specifically at the site of the new watch, which likely contains a component of nickel. Her rash does not appear to demonstrate the appropriate location or timeline to be presumed secondary to the perfume . As well, given the temporal and spatial relationship to the wearing of a new watch, along with erythematous papules, this is unlikely to represent a patch of dry skin (Choice C). Contact dermatitis occurs secondary to a type IV hypersensitivity reaction, which is T-cell dependent, not secondary to an impaired T-lymphocyte response (Choice E). ,. "' , r-- r ,,, Exam Section : Item 46 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
46. A 67-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 3-month history of a mass in his right groin that
intermittently appears and disappears spontaneously; over the past 3 hours , the mass has become increasingly painful , and
he has not been able to make it disappear . He also has had a decreased urinary stream and terminal dribbling with
urination . He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years . He has a daily nonproductive morning cough .
Abdominal examination shows no distention or tenderness . There is a nonreducible right groin mass ; the testes are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen with contrast

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Inguinal hernias can be subdivided into reducible, incarcerated, and strangulated categories. The contents of a reducible hernia easily return to their native position with gentle pressure, or with resolution of a triggering maneuver such as a Valsalva. The contents of incarcerated hernias become trapped within the hernia defect, and in spite of counterpressure, will not return to their native position. If this type of hernia contains bowel, an obstruction can result. Strangulated hernias occur when the herniated contents lose their blood supply, with the potential for necrosis or perforation. This patient presents with three months of symptoms suggestive of an inguinal hernia that was previously reducible, which explains its spontaneous appearance and disappearance. Now, he presents with three hours of increasing pain with inability to reduce the hernia, which indicates the hernia is incarcerated or strangulated. If a hernia cannot be manually reduced, surgical reduction is required in the setting of acute symptoms to prevent life-threatening complications .

distractor_explanations.A: CT scan of the abdomen with contrast would provide additional diagnostic information; however, the diagnosis can be made clinically with reasonable confidence on the basis of the history and physical exam alone. Imaging would delay definitive therapy without adding pertinent information to the clinical picture or advancing the course of therapy. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy (Choice B) would be an appropriate answer if the mass was consistent with lymphadenopathy; however, lymphadenopathy would not explain the previous three months of symptoms. Cystoscopy and urodynamic studies (Choice C) may be necessary to evaluate this patient's urinary symptoms, but he requires treatment for his acutely urgent presentation related to his inguinal hernia, not his nonurgent urinary issues. Incision and drainage (Choice D) would be appropriate therapy for an abscess; however, his presentation is suggestive of an incarcerated hernia as opposed to an abscess, which would present with erythema, fluctuance, and symptoms of local or systemic infection. ,. "' , r-- r ,,, Exam Section : Item 47 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
47. A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician 2 hours after the onset of headache and light-headedness . Her symptoms
began approximately 10 minutes after she ate mahimahi (dolphinfish), reheated rice, a lettuce salad , an unrefrigerated
cream puff, and unwashed raspberries . She appears slightly flushed . Which of the following is most likely to have prevented
her symptoms?

question_stem:
most likely to have prevented
her symptoms?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Scombroid poisoning results from ingestion of accumulated histamine, produced by bacteria from the high histidine content of dark meat fish. When ingested, the histamine triggers a reaction variably presenting with flushing, urticaria, wheezing, itchiness, blurry vision, abdominal cramping, diarrhea, and headache. In severe cases, it can present similarly to anaphylaxis. In this case, the mahimahi may have been improperly stored, leading to the accumulation of the histamine.

distractor_explanations.B: Refrigerating the cream puff might reduce the likelihood of S. aureus toxin-mediated diarrhea, but this would not fully or accurately explain the patient's symptoms. Reheated rice syndrome (Choice C) is occasionally seen due to infection from B. cereus, though typically presents with symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Unwashed leafy greens (Choice D) or berries (Choice E) could expose the patient to bacteria, fungi, viruses, or chemical contaminants, all of which would present with primarily gastrointestinal symptoms. ,. "' , r-- r ,,, Exam Section : Item 48 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment 48 . Twenty-four hours after nearly drowning, a 24-year-old man in the intensive care unit has not regained consciousness . He was resuscitated at the scene and was intubated and mechanically ventilated en route to the emergency department. In the emergency department , his Po was 80 mm Hg on an F10 of 30% . An x-ray of the 2 2 chest showed no abnormalities . Now, his temperature is 37.2°C (99°F) , pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 121/60 mm Hg. His respirations are 14/min on the ventilator. Examination shows no edema . Coarse airway sounds are heard on auscultation ; there are no crackles . Heart sounds are distant with no gallops . Laboratory studies show: Leukocyte count 8500/mm3 Segmented neutrophils 80% Lymphocytes 20% Serum creatinine 1.2 mg/dL Arterial blood gas analysis on an F10 of 100% and a positive end-expiratory pressure of 20 cm Hp shows : 2 7.42 38 mm Hg 60 mm Hg An x-ray of the chest is shown . Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current x-ray findings? A) Acute resRiratory distress syndrome B) Bronchiolitis obliterans C) Congestive heart failure D) Diffuse interstitial pneumonia E) Idiopathic interstitial fibrosis Correct Answer: A. Acute respiratory distress syndrome occurs in response to many etiologies, most commonly infectious, inflammatory, and traumatic. The syndrome results from the effect of cytokines on the pulmonary parenchyma from direct or indirect lung injury. This results in endothelial injury with exudative fluid extending into the alveolar space, resulting in diffuse alveolar damage and noncardiogenic pulmonary edema. On chest radiographs, this is characterized by diffuse reticular and airspace opacification. In the case of drowning, aspirated fluid causes local inflammation in the lung, along with the dilution of surfactant, leading to impaired compliance and airspace infiltration. This can result in persistent hypoxia despite rising positive end-expiratory pressure and increased fraction of inspired oxygen. Incorrect Answers: B, C, D, and E. Bronchiolitis obliterans (Choice B) is characterized by chronic inflammation in the bronchioles and, in some cases, alveoli, which leads to deposition of connective tissue and can show an obstructive lung disease pattern on spirometry. Congestive heart failure (Choice C) results from increased filling pressures or impaired forward flow in the heart. This increases hydrostatic pressure in the pulmonary venous circulation, resulting in transudation of fluid from the pulmonary capillaries into the alveolar space, impairing gas exchange. It is not the most likely etiology in a previously healthy young person without cardiomegaly on chest x-ray and a more likely explanation related to recent drowning. Diffuse interstitial pneumonia (Choice D) commonly presents with infectious or inflammatory symptoms such as fever and cough productive of sputum, along with infiltrates on chest x-ray. This patient is afebrile and had a normal chest x-ray on arrival that became abnormal during the hospital course, suggesting that prior to presentation he had been healthy. Idiopathic interstitial fibrosis (Choice E), also known as idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, is a restrictive lung disease that often presents in older smokers, resulting in chronic and progressive shortness of breath. r-- r " , r , Exam Section : Item 49 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
49. A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after he was involved in a motor vehicle collision in
which he was the unrestrained driver of a car without an air bag. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 15 years .
On arrival, he has severe chest pain that is most severe on inspiration. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs
113 kg (250 lb); BMI is 38 kg/m 2 His pulse is 130/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg.
•
Examination shows an ecchymosis over the anterior chest; there is no evidence of fractures . The lungs are clear to
auscultation. An x-ray of the chest shows interstitial infiltrates of the lungs bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely
cause of this patient's respiratory symptoms?

question_stem:
the most likely
cause of this patient's respiratory symptoms?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Pulmonary contusions may occur after blunt or penetrating trauma to the chest. They often underlie the region of trauma to the chest wall and result from damage to capillaries with associated leakage of intravascular and extravascular fluid into the pulmonary interstitium and alveolar airspaces, respectively. This can result in hypoxia if it involves and compromises a large enough region of the lung. On chest radiographs, pulmonary contusions appear as interstitial infiltrates and/or patchy alveolar opacities. The extent and distribution depend on the mechanism, location, and force of trauma to the chest wall. Management of pulmonary contusions is supportive with control of pain, pulmonary toilet, lung expansion, and maintenance of adequate ventilation/oxygenation of the patient.

distractor_explanations.A: Fat embolism typically occurs following a long-bone fracture with resultant fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypoxia, petechiae, and conjunctiva! hemorrhage. Flail chest (Choice B) generally results when two or more adjacent ribs are fractured at two or more locations, which results in paradoxical movement of that particular segment of the chest wall. Pulmonary edema (Choice D) often occurs secondary to a hypervolemic state (eg, heart failure, renal failure, cirrhosis) or inflammatory state (eg, pneumonia , acute respiratory distress syndrome) and can present with tachypnea, tachycardia, hypoxia, cough, respiratory distress, and interstitial and/or alveolar opacities. Pulmonary thromboembolism (Choice E) presents with tachycardia, tachypnea, and pleuritic chest pain, and is unlikely to be related to trauma acutely, though can result from prolonged immobilization following trauma if a thrombus develops and embolizes. ,. "' , r-- r ,,, Exam Section : Item 50 of 50 Medicine Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
50. A 27-year-old woman with systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of
progressive shortness of breath. Examination shows decreased lung expansion, neck vein distention, and a parasternal
heave; diffuse inspiratory crackles are heard on auscultation . She has 3+ pedal edema bilaterally. Which of the following is
the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cor pulmonale refers to isolated right heart failure secondary to chronic pulmonary pathology with increased pulmonary vascular resistance and right-sided heart pressures. This patient has a history of systemic sclerosis (scleroderma), with decreased lung expansion and inspiratory crackles on examination, indicating the presence of underlying interstitial lung disease (ILD) and a restrictive pulmonary pathophysiology. Chronic ILD is a risk factor for the development of pulmonary hypertension. Right heart failure presents with venous congestion, seen as jugular venous distention, peripheral edema, and hepatomegaly with or without ascites. The patient exhibits all of these symptoms, making cor pulmonale secondary to ILD the most likely clinical scenario .

distractor_explanations.A: Angioedema refers to the rapid development of swelling beneath the skin or mucosa related to histamine and/or bradykinin release in the setting of an allergic exposure, use of an ACE inhibitor, or from C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency. Superior vena cava obstruction (Choice B) occurs from obstruction of venous drainage from the head and bilateral upper extremities, often related to an underlying malignancy and associated mass effect, or from thrombosis from an indwelling catheter. Biventricular heart failure (Choice C) refers to heart failure of both the left and right ventricles. Left heart failure presents with symptoms such as paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, and pulmonary edema, which are not seen in this patient. Cirrhosis of the liver (Choice D) occurs secondary to many etiologies, the most common being alcoholic and non alcoholic fatty liver disease. Cirrhosis presents with ascites, anasarca, jaundice , elevated transaminases, low albumin, and impaired hepatic synthetic function .
