Idiopathic membranous nephropathy (Choice F) is the most common cause of primary nephrotic syndrome and results from many etiologies (eg, non-steroidal anti inflammatory drug use, hepatitis viruses, systemic lupus erythematosus) and typically presents with massive proteinuria, edema, hyperlipidemia, and a hypercoagulable state. Lymphedema (Choice G) refers to swelling secondary to abnormal lymphatic drainage of a region , often secondary to surgery, radiation, or invasive parasitiasis . Myxedema (Choice H) refers to facial and periorbital swelling in the setting of hypothyroidism. Pretibial myxedema may be seen in Graves disease . Venous insufficiency (Choice I) often occurs secondary to a history of deep venous thrombosis; it can lead to stasis dermatitis and cutaneous ulcers of the affected extremity. ,. is 37.2°C (99°F) , pulse is 64/min and irregularly irregular, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg

polysaccharide vaccine, 23-valent, at that time. He received a tetanus booster 5 years ago and the hepatitis A and B vaccines 3 years ago. He had all appropriate childhood
vaccinations. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a CD4+ T-lymphocyte count of 643/mm3 (Normal2500) and
an undetectable plasma HIV viral load. Which of the following vaccinations is most appropriate at this time?

question_stem: most appropriate at this time?

choices.text: No vaccines are indicated at this time

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Influenza is a respiratory viral illness that can be complicated by lower respiratory tract infections and/or bacterial superinfections, especially in elderly or immunocompromised patients. Symptoms include fever, chills, cough, myalgias, malaise, headaches, nausea, and vomiting. The Centers for Disease Control recommends annual influenza virus vaccination for all patients greater than 6 months of age. The influenza vaccine is available as a trivalent or quadrivalent intramuscular injection of inactivated virus or as a nasal spray of live attenuated virus. Inactivated influenza virus vaccine can be safely administered via intramuscular injection to patients with HIV, who may be at a higher risk for severe illness and influenza-related complications. Influenza is a seasonal illness, typically affecting patients from the late fall to early spring months. This patient is travelling during the autumn months and should receive the vaccination for influenza virus.

distractor_explanations.A: is sexually transmitted and is associated with genital warts along with premalignant and malignant lesions of the cervical, anogenital, and oropharyngeal regions. HPV vaccines have significantly decreased the incidence and prevalence of HPV and protect against HPV-related malignancies such as cervical and anal squamous cell carcinoma. The vaccine should ideally be administered before the teenage years because the immune response is most robust, and the onset of sexual activity may occur during the teenage years. HPV vaccine is not specifically recommended prior to travel. 2. A 92-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after she was found confused in her home. The weather has been extremely hot, and the
temperature in her room was 97°F. She has multi-infarct (vascular) dementia and had a myocardial infarction 30 years ago. She is stuporous. Her temperature is 39°C
(102.2°F), pulse is 130/min and regular, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. There is no jugular venous
distention. The lungs are clear on auscultation. A grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur is heard at the lower left sternal border. The remainder of the examination shows no
abnormalities. Test of the stool for occult blood is negative. Which of the following age-related changes is the most likely explanation for the findings in this patient?

question_stem: the most likely explanation for the findings in this patient?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Heat stroke is characterized by an increased body temperature that occurs when the body is exposed to high environmental temperatures and high humidity. Excessive heat exposure and increased core body temperature lead to cardiovascular and neurologic dysfunction with secondary tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotension. Vasodilation of superficial blood vessels may lead to multi-organ system failure, including hepatic and renal ischemia, rhabdomyolysis, and disseminated intravascular coagulation. Treatment includes cooling of the patient with fans or ice water, continuous core temperature monitoring, and support of airways, breathing, and circulation. Heat stroke generally requires neurologic symptoms to be diagnosed, whereas heat exhaustion presents similarly but with normal neurologic examination. Heat stroke commonly occurs in young athletes or in elderly patients with impaired thermoregulatory capacity, as evidenced by impaired thirst, blood vessel dilation, and reduced ability to sweat, all reducing the ability to dissipate heat.

3. A 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of fever and confusion for 4 hours. She has a 5-year history of systemic lupus erythematosus. She had
Neisseria meningitidis meningitis 3 years ago. Current medications include hydroxychloroquine. Her temperature is 40°C (104°F). Examination shows nuchal rigidity. Kernig
sign is present. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows cloudiness. A Gram stain shows gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following mechanisms is the most likely cause of
these findings?

question_stem:
the most likely cause of
these findings?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Deficiency of terminal components of complement is the most likely cause of this patient's recent and recurrent infection with Neisseria meningitidis. The presence of fever, nuchal rigidity, and cerebrospinal fluid analysis demonstrating gram-negative diplococci is diagnostic for bacterial meningitis. Deficiency of terminal complement factors (eg, C5—C9) impairs the formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC) and predisposes patients to infection with Neisseria species, although infections tend to occur with uncommon serotypes. While the complement cascade can be activated via the classical, lectin, or alternative pathways, each pathway converges on the same point whereby C3 is cleaved to release C3a and C3b. The C3 convertase complex subsequently leads to activation of C5, with formation of C5a and C5b, the latter of which complexes with C6, C7, C8, and C9 to form the MAC. The MAC creates a transmembrane pore that interferes with the integrity of the cellular membrane, leading to cell lysis. Screening for terminal complement deficiency usually starts with determination of the CH50, a diagnostic test that measures the ability of the patient's serum to lyse sheep erythrocytes coated with antibodies directed against erythrocyte membrane proteins. Because this test measures the activity of factors C1-C9, a deficiency at any point will lead to an abnormal result, although in patients with terminal complement deficiency, the CH50 concentration will be very decreased or even zero. In addition to treating infections, further treatment should include vaccination against N. meningitidis, H. influenzae, and S. pneumoniae.

37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Examination shows mild splenomegaly. Laboratory studies show:

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) is the most likely diagnosis in this asymptomatic male with splenomegaly, thrombocytosis, and leukocytosis with a white blood cell (WBC) differential demonstrating cells of different lineages. CML is diagnosed by the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, which causes constitutive activation of the ABL kinase protein. Activation of ABL kinase leads to subsequent activation of the JAK/STAT and Ras/MAPK/ERK pathways, leading to increased hematopoietic proliferation, inhibition of normal checkpoint inhibition, and resistance to apoptosis. Typical laboratory findings in CML include leukocytosis with an increase in nearly all cell lines. Basophilia and eosinophilia are particularly characteristic. Splenomegaly, which at times can be massive, is common. Leukostasis, a condition in which leukocytosis leads to end organ damage from occlusion of capillaries by malignant cells, is uncommon in CML. Iron deficiency anemia (IDA) manifests as decreased serum iron concentration, increased TIBC, and decreased ferritin. Calculation of the transferrin saturation is also useful. vignette.presentation:
7. Prior to discharge to a skilled nursing care facility, an 80-year-old woman is evaluated in the hospital because of a decreased hemoglobin concentration. She underwent
hemicolectomy 10 days ago for gastrointestinal bleeding secondary to diverticulosis. Four units of packed red blood cells were transfused during the procedure. She has
hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her medications are lisinopril and metformin. Today, her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 14/min,
and blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mucosal pallor and conjunctival icterus. Abdominal examination shows a well-healing incision. Baseline
hemoglobin concentration on postoperative day 3 was 10.0 g/dL . Hemoglobin concentration today is 7.5 g/dL . Laboratory studies are most likely to show which of the
following additional findings?
Direct Antiglobulin Serum Bilirubin
(Coombs) Test Concentration

question_stem:
most likely to show which of the
following additional findings?
Direct Antiglobulin Serum Bilirubin
(Coombs) Test Concentration

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Laboratory studies are most likely to disclose a positive direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test and an increased serum concentration of indirect (unconjugated) bilirubin, which is consistent with a hemolytic transfusion reaction. This patient's presentation 10 days following blood transfusion, and not immediately during transfusion, suggests a delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction (DHTR). In contrast to acute hemolytic transfusion reactions, which arise because of ABO incompatibility and can be life-threatening, DHTRs usually result from the presence of autoantibodies against minor erythrocyte antigens (eg, Rh antigens). In all cases, DHTR requires prior exposure to the antigen for the patient to produce antibodies, but in some instances, the antibodies may not be found in titers during routine blood bank screening to be appropriately recognized. The Coombs test involves incubating the patient's erythrocytes with anti-IgG and anti-complement antibody known as Coombs reagent. If an autoantibody or complement is bound to the surface of the erythrocytes, the Coombs reagent will bind to it and cause agglutination resulting in a positive test. The fixation of complement results in intravascular hemolysis and an increased indirect bilirubin while binding of antibodies to the surface of erythrocytes may mark them for removal in the reticuloendothelial system. In either case, patients present with anemia and evidence of hemolysis. Treatment is supportive.
explanation.educational_objective: Delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions typically occur within 1 to 2 weeks following erythrocyte transfusion and are usually the result of pre-formed antibodies against minor erythrocyte antigens. Diagnosis is suggested by the presence of a positive Coombs test, indirect hyperbilirubinemia, and anemia. (4 > (4 @ €C > m

resolved spontaneously. His last visit to a physician was 35 years ago. His pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 160/96 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a diffuse point of
maximal impulse and an S, gallop. A left femoral bruit is heard. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 9.7 g/dL
Serum
Glucose (nonfasting) 156 mg/dL
Creatinine 3.2 mg/dL
Total cholesterol 210 mg/dL
An ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy. Treatment of which of the following is most likely to have prevented these findings?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's presenting symptoms of transient weakness and dysarthria or aphasia are consistent with transient ischemic attack (TIA), defined as a transient episode of neurologic dysfunction caused by focal brain, spinal cord, or retinal ischemia without evidence of infarction. Additionally, this patient presents with signs of congestive heart failure (CHF), peripheral vascular disease, and chronic kidney disease (CKD), including an enlarged point of maximal impulse, an S4 gallop, a femoral bruit, and an increased creatinine, respectively. This patient has multiple risk factors for a TIA and ischemic stroke including hypertension, diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia, and atherosclerotic disease. Hypertension is the single most important modifiable risk factor for TIAs and ischemic strokes and is an important contributor to the development of CHF, CKD, and peripheral vascular disease.

9. An otherwise healthy 92-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her family because of a 1-year history of cognitive decline. Her daughter reports that the patient seems
to “fish for words" and often repeats questions. The patient's 94-year-old husband has not noticed a problem. Twenty years ago, she sustained a concussion after falling off a
horse. She is a high school graduate. Her 90-year-old sister has significant memory problems; her two younger brothers have no memory problems. The patient takes no
medications. On examination, she is pleasant and cooperative. She knows the year, but not the month or date. She can recall a recent holiday. She has no difficulty naming
objects by sight, but when asked to name as many animals as she can in 1 minute, she can only name five. She recalls one of three items after 5 minutes. Which of the
following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Alzheimer disease (AD) is the most common type of dementia. It typically presents with progressive cognitive deterioration that begins with short-term memory impairment and a decline in visuospatial abilities, which progresses to apraxia, language abnormalities, and dysexecutive syndrome. The disease culminates in behavioral and personality changes that prevent the patient from performing basic activities of daily living, such as bathing. Age is the strongest risk factor for AD. The incidence of AD approximately doubles every 5 years after age

vignette.presentation:

and indirectly increase acetylcholine in synaptic clefts. These include donepezil and cholinesterase inhibitors, which non-competitively and reversibly inhibit acetylcholinesterase,
thereby increasing the amount of synaptic acetylcholine available for neurotransmission. Though these drugs may slow the rate of cognitive decline and modestly improve
functionality, they are not curative for AD.
Incorrect Answers: B, C, D, and E.
Education level (Choice B) has been linked to AD. Some studies have demonstrated a lower incidence of AD in populations with a higher level of education. This relationship,
however, is not as significant as age as a predisposing factor for AD.
Family history (Choice C) is a mild risk factor for AD. Patients with a first-degree relative with AD have a modestly increased risk for developing AD. While there are rare cases of
dominantly inherited mutations that lead to early onset familial AD, most cases of AD are sporadic.

10. A previously healthy 42-year-old man comes to the office because of severe right-sided headaches for the past 3 weeks. He says that he awakens every night at 3 AM with a

sharp stabbing pain behind the right eye that usually lasts about 30 minutes. There is no associated nausea. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 25 years and

drinks a six-pack of beer daily. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination during an episode shows ptosis on the right and tearing and conjunctival injection; the right

pupil is 2 mm, and the left is 4 mm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cluster headaches are primary headaches that typically present with brief (<120 minutes), unilateral, severe pain in the orbital, supraorbital, or temporal region of the head and are accompanied by ipsilateral autonomic symptoms. The pathogenesis is incompletely understood but likely involves activation of sensory fibers of the trigeminal nerve and parasympathetic nerves. Autonomic symptoms commonly include ptosis, miosis, lacrimation, conjunctival injection, rhinorrhea, and/or nasal congestion. Patients typically present between the ages of 20 and 50 years and are often male. Cigarette and alcohol use may be triggers for patients with a history of cluster headaches. The headaches often recur over a series of weeks to months, sometimes at the same time each year. Oxygen therapy with 100% oxygen is the most effective first-line abortive treatment, and verapamil is the first-line prophylactic treatment. The clinician should always distinguish primary headache types (eg, tension, cluster, migraine) from secondary headache types (eg, intracranial bleeding, tumors, glaucoma) because the treatment and prognosis differ greatly.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Seborrheic keratosis is a benign proliferation of the epidermis. It is characterized histologically by a benign, acanthotic proliferation of keratinocytes with absence of cellular atypia. The lesions are typically round, raised, brown or tan in color, and sharply demarcated with an adherent or stuck-on appearance. Seborrheic keratosis is common in middle-aged and older adults and is most associated with increasing age. While seborrheic keratosis is benign, the sudden appearance of numerous seborrheic keratosis lesions on the back and trunk, known as the Leser-Trélat sign, can be a paraneoplastic manifestation of gastrointestinal malignancy. No treatment is necessary for seborrheic keratosis, although lesions that are cosmetically bothersome may be removed with cryotherapy or simple excision.

12. A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of persistent actinic keratosis despite treatment with 5-fluorouracil. Examination

the most appropriate next step in

choices.text: Systemic chemotherapy followed by surgical excision
Systemic chemotherapy followed by surgical excision

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Actinic keratosis is a premalignant lesion that may progress to squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). Clinically, lesions typically appear as light pink, ill-defined macules with a gritty texture in areas of prolonged sun exposure, such as the face, ears, and dorsal hands. Actinic keratosis may be treated with topical medications, such as 5-fluorouracil or imiquimod, excision, cryotherapy, or dermabrasion. Ablative therapies are best used when the diagnosis is relatively certain, and a histopathologic specimen is not required. Lack of response to topical therapy should raise suspicion for possible SCC and should prompt an excisional biopsy. A low threshold of suspicion for SCC should be maintained particularly in patients with a history of immunocompromise or solid organ transplantation. Excisional biopsy is preferable because of its ability to assess for invasive disease and curative potential if the entire lesion is removed.

distractor_explanations.A: is not appropriate because this patient's actinic keratosis has failed to respond to prior topical treatment, which raises suspicion for possible SCC. Punch biopsy (
distractor_explanations.C: is not preferred for the diagnosis and treatment of lesions concerning for SCC because it does not allow for the complete removal of the lesion. SCC lesions that are incompletely excised usually require further excision with careful assessment of the margins. Radiation therapy (
distractor_explanations.D: is not typically used for lesions that are concerning for SCC. Radiation is sometimes used in conjunction with surgical excision in high-risk SCC tumors or in lesions that are not amenable to complete excision. explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Septic arthritis is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus and presents with pain, inability to bear weight, reduced range of motion, fever, chills, nausea, myalgias, arthralgias, and fatigue. Vital signs may show fever, tachycardia, or hypotension in cases of septic shock. Physical examination typically discloses tenderness to palpation of the affected joint, a limited range of motion, pain with range of motion, joint effusion, and overlying cutaneous erythema. Potential routes of infection include direct inoculation, spread from an adjacent infection such as osteomyelitis, or hematogenous seeding. A structurally compromised joint, such as a prosthetic joint or a joint affected by years of inflammatory arthropathy may be more susceptible to infection, especially if the patient is also systemically imnmunocompromised. Diagnosis is through clinical examination plus arthrocentesis, which classically discloses a neutrophilic-predominant exudate with a white blood cell count of greater than 50,000/mm3. Organisms are often seen on gram stain and are detected by culture. Treatment includes intravenous antibiotics plus emergent operative debridement to prevent complications such as articular erosion, fibrous ankylosis, loss of the ability to ambulate, and the potential for sepsis and death, if severe.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The supraspinatus tendon is the most common location of rotator cuff injury. The supraspinatus muscle lies within the supraspinous fossa along the superior portion of the scapula, and its tendon inserts on the greater tuberosity of the humerus. The supraspinatus muscle contributes to the initiation of arm abduction prior to the action of the deltoid muscle. Injury to the supraspinatus tendon may occur from degeneration, impingement, overuse, or trauma and can be evaluated through abduction of the shoulder against resistance. Classic symptoms include pain with active shoulder abduction during which time the tendon is placed under tension by the muscle, which is relieved with passive abduction as no tension is generated on the part of the patient. Treatment includes rest, ice, anti-inflammatory medications, and physical therapy.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Colchicine, a microtubule inhibitor, is commonly used in the treatment of inflammatory arthropathies such as gout. It acts by preventing the activation and migration of neutrophils to a site of inflammation, though several mechanisms beyond this are proposed. Gout is an acute monoarticular arthropathy resulting from an intraarticular inflammatory reaction to the precipitation of monosodium urate crystals within the joint space. Precipitation can result from the overproduction of uric acid but more commonly occurs following the underexcretion of uric acid. Gout typically presents with acute, atraumatic single-joint pain, erythema, and swelling, which can recur in patients who are under- or untreated. The most common joint involved is the first metatarsophalangeal, as shown in the photograph, but other common joints include the knees and elbows. Diagnosis occurs through arthrocentesis, which will disclose needle-shaped, birefringent crystals. Certain medications (eg, loop diuretics), malignancy, and existing joint disease are predisposing conditions. Treatment consists of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), colchicine, and/or corticosteroids for acute exacerbations. Chronic preventive management involves the use of xanthine oxidase inhibitors such as allopurinol. Additionally, patients should avoid triggering risk factors such as purine-rich meals and heavy alcohol consumption.
explanation.educational_objective: Colchicine, a microtubule inhibitor, is commonly used in the management of gout, which typically presents with an acute inflammatory arthritis. Colchicine inhibits ongoing inflammation, which permits resolution of the symptoms of gout. Gout can be prevented by avoiding triggering medications and by limiting intake of purine-rich foods in addition to the use of xanthine oxidase inhibitors and medications for long-term control. explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Aortic atherosclerosis commonly occurs at the aortic arch, where it serves as a major risk factor for cerebral embolism, and in the abdominal aorta distal to the renal arteries. Aortic atherosclerosis may lead to ischemia of the lower extremities, presenting with claudication of the buttocks and legs, lower extremity pain, paresthesia, paraplegia, shiny, hairless skin, and erectile dysfunction. A careful examination with attention to lower extremity pulses is crucial to distinguish an acute or chronic ischemic cause from potential neurologic causes. The diagnosis of aortic atherosclerosis is supported by CT or MR angiography along with assessment of ankle brachial blood pressure indices. Prompt reperfusion is essential to prevent further loss of function caused by hypoperfusion and can be accomplished with balloon or stent angioplasty, aortic endarterectomy, vascular bypass surgery (eg, aortofemoral bypass grafting), or thrombolysis or thrombectomy in cases of acute plaque rupture or embolic occlusion. Modifiable risk factors for aortic atherosclerotic disease include smoking, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, and cocaine use.

Claudication is not a typical symptom. Aortic aneurysms are generally asymptomatic until they rupture, which generally presents with acute abdominal pain and hypotension and is often fatal if not promptly identified and surgically managed. explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The presentation of pericardial effusion may range from asymptomatic to severe, symptomatic cardiac tamponade in large-volume or rapidly accumulating cases. Compression of the cardiac chambers, especially the right ventricle, impairs cardiac filling and decreases cardiac output (low stroke volume). Presenting features include but are not limited to a history of chest discomfort, shortness of breath, decreased exercise tolerance, fluid retention, and lightheadedness, along with any historical feature that may explain the cause of effusion (eg, weight loss or history of malignancy in cases of malignant effusion). Vital signs may be normal in cases of small effusions or may include tachycardia and hypotension in cases of tamponade. Physical examination findings include Beck triad (hypotension, distended jugular veins, and distant heart sounds) in the case of tamponade. These findings occur because of the presence of fluid in the pericardial space muffling heart sounds and increasing collapsing pressure on the right ventricle, which is transmitted to the vena cavae and their tributaries. In such a manner, increased right heart pressure is reflected as increased jugular venous distention (JVD). ECG may disclose low voltage and/or electrical alternans. There may be pulsus paradoxus on evaluation of blood pressure. Confirmatory diagnosis requires visualization of the effusion, often on echocardiogram. Mild or asymptomatic cases may be managed conservatively with watchful waiting and treatment of any predisposing conditions, whereas moderate, symptomatic, or severe cases, especially if accompanied by hemodynamic instability require treatment with pericardiocentesis or a pericardial window to restore diastolic filling and cardiac output. Predisposing conditions include but are not limited to malignancy, infectious or inflammatory states such as tuberculosis, pericarditis, or systemic lupus erythematosus, traumatic injury, and aortic dissection. It may present with JVD and edema but would not generally present with electrical alternans and low voltage on ECG. ECG findings may include signs of right ventricular hypertrophy. Pulmonary emboli (

The physical examination is often normal, though occasionally signs of right heart strain can be detected, such as JVD and peripheral edema. The ECG may disclose normal sinus rhythm or sinus tachycardia, right axis deviation, signs of right heart strain such as right bundle branch blocks and right ventricular hypertrophy, or the $1Q3T3 pattern.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Aortic dissection classically presents with severe, acute, tearing chest or abdominal pain radiating to the back and differential blood pressures between extremities with asymmetric pulses. Dissection begins with a disruption of the tunica intima of the vessel, which permits blood to dissect the layers of the vessel wall with each heartbeat. A dissection flap may advance in any direction within the vessel, occluding or involving branch ostia. If vessel takeoffs supplying the limbs are affected, pulse deficits or differential blood pressures may arise. If splanchnic vessels are involved, end-organ dysfunction such as mesenteric ischemia or acute kidney injury may be seen. Management may be medical or surgical and depends on the location of the dissection within the vessel (eg, Type A vs Type B). Regardless of the need for surgery, all patients with dissection should receive immediate medical management to prevent further progression of the flap. Controlling the patient's heart rate and blood pressure is the priority in preventing progression. Intravenous B-adrenergic blocking medications should be used with a goal of lowering the heart rate to approximately 60 beats per minute and the blood pressure to less than 100 to 120 mm Hg systolic and 60 to 80 mm Hg diastolic. Lowering the heart rate helps prevent the advancement of the dissection flap and resultant occlusion of branch vessels by limiting the pulse pressure differential. Complications such as stroke, acute coronary syndrome, and cardiac tamponade may be immediately life-threatening. (4 > (4 @ tial > m

Acute iliac occlusion generally presents with a cool, painful, pale lower extremity, motor weakness, paresthesia, pulse deficit, and differential blood pressure. Chronic occlusive disease may present with claudication, hair loss, shiny skin, atrophy, and impotence. Renal artery embolus (
distractor_explanations.B: may present with abdominal, flank, or back pain and costovertebral angle tenderness on examination, decreased urine output, or hematuria in cases of resultant infarction. It would not generally present with symptoms involving the extremities. Ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (
distractor_explanations.C: classically presents with tearing abdominal pain radiating to the back and a pulsatile abdominal mass in an older person with history of smoking, hypertension, connective tissue disease, or known atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. Rupture first occurs into the retroperitoneal space, where it may remain transiently contained. If exsanguination continues, rupture may involve the peritoneal cavity, at which time rapid and unmitigated exsanguination can occur. Similarly, a ruptured thoracic aneurysm (
distractor_explanations.D: presents with tearing chest pain radiating to the back, though unless branch vessels are involved, the physical examination may be normal apart from the variable presence of a murmur. The most common presentation of both aneurysms, which are often occult for years, is at the time of rupture, at which time they may present with severe pain and signs of hemorrhagic shock. Treatment includes fluid resuscitation and/or blood transfusion, along with emergent operative or procedural repair.

explanation.educational_objective: Aortic dissection classically presents with severe, acute, tearing chest or abdominal pain radiating to the back and differential blood pressures between extremities with asymmetric pulses. Complications and additional presenting features depend on the involvement of branch vessels (eg, stroke resulting from carotid occlusion, mesenteric ischemia from mesenteric arterial occlusion, renal infarction from renal artery occlusion). Treatment involves fluid resuscitation along with rapidly lowering blood pressure and heart rate to prevent advancement of the dissection flap and surgical or procedural intervention, if appropriate. explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Atrial fibrillation describes the uncoordinated contraction of the cardiac atria and is often the result of chronic left atrial enlargement caused by mitral regurgitation or increased left sided pressures (eg, in left ventricular hypertrophy with diastolic dysfunction). When the atria do not uniformly fill and contract, blood can become stagnant in areas of the atria, especially in the left atrial appendage. Blood in stasis is prone to coagulate, which results in the formation of a thrombus within the cardiac chambers. If a portion of such a thrombus embolizes, many clinical syndromes can result. For example, strokes occur when a thromboembolism occludes cerebral circulation, mesenteric ischemia occurs when the mesenteric arteries are occluded, and acute limb ischemia occurs when an artery supplying an extremity becomes occluded. Management of atrial fibrillation includes anticoagulation with warfarin or a direct oral anticoagulant (eg, apixaban) to prevent the formation of atrial thrombus, which reduces the risk for thromboembolic complications.

distractor_explanations.A: is indicated in the prevention of acute coronary syndromes and cerebrovascular accidents. It has not been shown to reduce the risk for thromboembolic complications in atrial fibrillation. Commonly, patients with atrial fibrillation are at increased risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, many of whom will therefore be on aspirin (an anti-platelet agent) in addition to an anticoagulant. Digoxin therapy (
distractor_explanations.B: is indicated in the management of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and is also sometimes used for rate control in atrial fibrillation in cases where B-adrenergic blockers or calcium channel blockers are insufficient. It does not directly influence the coagulation cascade. (4 > (4 @ tial > m

explanation.educational_objective: Anticoagulation is indicated in cases of atrial fibrillation to prevent the formation of atrial thrombus, which reduces the risk for thromboembolic complications such as strokes, mesenteric ischemia, and limb ischemia. Warfarin and direct oral anticoagulants (eg, apixaban) are commonly employed agents. (4 > (4 @ tial > m

and mild shortness of breath. During the procedure, a peritoneal drain was placed. Postoperatively, intravenous ciprofloxacin and metronidazole therapy was begun. A
persistent ileus was diagnosed on postoperative day 2, and a nasogastric tube was inserted. Yesterday, the nasogastric tube was removed, and he was advanced to a
regular diet. Today, his temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows
an oxygen saturation of 94%. Crackles are heard at the mid left lung field. Abdominal examination shows a clean, dry surgical incision. The peritoneal drain is mostly clear of
fluid. Leukocyte count is 15,100/mm3 (65% segmented neutrophils, 10% bands, 25% lymphocytes). Chest x-rays are shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate
next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Pneumonia classically presents with acute onset cough (generally productive of sputum), shortness of breath, chest discomfort, fever, chills, and fatigue. Vital signs may show fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypoxemia, and hypotension (if severe). On examination, rhonchi and rales may be detected in consolidated lung, along with egophony and dullness to percussion. Patients may have increased work of breathing or respiratory distress. The diagnosis is supported radiographically with airspace disease or consolidation visualized on x-ray, as shown here, or on CT. Pneumonia arises because of the presence of bacteria, virus, parasite, or fungi within pulmonary parenchyma, triggering an inflammatory reaction with resultant exudate into airspace. It is common in hospitalized patients because of risk factors for introduction of a pathogen, aspiration, and immunocompromise, including recent surgery, swallowing dysfunction, and intubation. Additionally, resistant pathogens often colonize hospitals and equipment, increasing the risk for refractory infection despite coadministration of antibiotics. Treatment of hospital-acquired pneumonia generally begins with the administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics (especially those covering methicillin resistant S. aureus [MRSA] and P. aeruginosa) while awaiting culture and sensitivity data from sputum samples if obtained. Suitable antibiotics for this purpose include vancomycin and third- or fourth-generation cephalosporins such as ceftazidime or cefepime. Antibiotics should then be narrowed to those that suitably target the infecting agent once a clinical response is achieved. Reduction in risk factors should occur, such as upright positioning of patients, removal of any unnecessary pharyngeal lines or tubes (eg, nasogastric tubes), and frequent respiratory therapy/pulmonary toileting. Postoperative pain, often worse when breathing, should be aggressively managed to permit full chest excursion, promote coughing and respiratory clearance, and limit atelectasis. (4 > (4 @ €C > m

Common pathogens in CAP include S. pneumoniae, and atypical organisms such as L. pneumophila and M. pneumoniae. Neither of these agents sufficiently cover common hospital-acquired pathogens. Administration of sulfamethoxazole and cefuroxime (
distractor_explanations.B: may not be sufficiently broad to cover aggressive or resistant pathogens found in hospital-acquired infections. Bronchoscopy for microbiologic assessment (
distractor_explanations.D: may be necessary when initial treatment of infection does not lead to clinical improvement, or when there is diagnostic uncertainty as to the suspected pathogen at hand. Empiric treatment in uncomplicated cases generally precedes bronchoscopy. In general, induced, expectorated, or aspirated samples can be obtained. Such methods are less invasive and resource-consuming than bronchoscopy, though such samples may be contaminated with oropharyngeal flora making microbiologic diagnosis more challenging. CT scan of the chest with pulmonary embolism protocol (
distractor_explanations.E: is appropriate in cases of suspected pulmonary embolism, which presents with pleuritic chest pain, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypoxia, and with signs of deep vein thrombosis on examination. Unless lung parenchyma is infarcted, lung sounds are otherwise normal.

23. A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of nonproductive cough, hemoptysis, and a 9-kg (20-Ib) weight loss over the past month. He has smoked two packs of

cigarettes daily for 50 years. Breath sounds are decreased over the right posterior hemithorax. Laboratory studies show no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest shows

collapse of the right lower lobe of the lung. Which of the following is the most likely pathophysiology of this patient's condition?

question_stem: the most likely pathophysiology of this patient's condition?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Lung cancer often remains asymptomatic until advanced stage, at which time the tumor has locally invaded or metastasized, leading to the development of symptoms. The initial presentation is often nonspecific, including weight loss and fatigue. Once the tumor has invaded or involved neurosensory and vascular structures, patients may begin to experience coughing and hemoptysis. If the lesion is large enough to invade or obstruct a bronchus, patients may also experience post-obstructive or recurrent pneumonia in parenchyma distal to the lesion, caused by atelectasis and impaired endobronchial clearance of mucus, secretions, and inhaled pathogens. In this patient, the decreased breath sounds over the right posterior hemithorax suggest the presence of an endobronchial obstruction to airflow; this is further supported by atelectasis on x-ray in the corresponding area. Squamous cell carcinoma and small cell carcinoma of the lung tend to be centrally occurring lesions, often seen in smokers. Non-small cell carcinoma and other subtypes are more often peripherally occurring and may be more common in nonsmokers. Because of the significant morbidity and mortality with late diagnosis, screening low-dose chest CT is recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force in patients aged 50 to 80 years with a 20 pack-year smoking history and who currently smoke or have quit within the past 15 years.

On examination, rales may be heard, generally in dependent areas. X-ray generally discloses bilateral airspace edema, cephalization of the vessels, Kerley B lines, pleural effusions, and cardiomegaly. having shortness of breath. He now has shortness of breath after walking one block. He has not had chest pain, palpitations, swelling of his legs, or shortness of breath at
night. He has hypertension. His medications are lisinopril and aspirin. He does not smoke cigarettes. He is a retired foundry worker. He is 183 cm (6 ft) tall and weighs 82 kg
(180 Ib); BMI is 24 kg/m2. His pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%.
Diffuse crackles are heard bilaterally. Cardiac examination shows no other abnormalities. There is no edema of the extremities. Results of pulmonary function testing show
an FVC of 65% of predicted and an FEV ,:FVC ratio of 70%. A chest x-ray is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Pneumoconiosis describes interstitial lung disease arising because of inhalation of small solid particulate matter such as dust or powder (eg, talc, silica, beryllium, and ores) that leads to the development of fibrosis with resultant restrictive lung disease. It is often seen in patients with chronic exposures, such as foundry workers, miners, shipyard workers, cotton workers, farmers, stone drillers, and sandblasters. The disease's progress is often worsened by smoking. It generally presents with chronic symptoms of cough and shortness of breath on exertion; when severe or advanced, it can be associated with the need for supplemental oxygen and symptoms of heart failure (eg, cor pulmonale). Diagnosis is based on clinical history, symptoms, examination, exposure history, characteristic imaging tests that show fibrosis (x-ray may show honeycombing and fibrosis, especially in the apices), and pulmonary function tests that disclose a restrictive pattern of lung disease marked by decreased overall volumes and capacities but a preserved or increased ratio of FEV ,:FVC. This ratio is a key distinguishing feature from obstructive lung disease, which generally presents with a decrease in the ratio.
explanation.educational_objective: Pneumoconiosis describes interstitial lung disease arising because of inhalation of small solid particulate matter such as dust or powder that leads to the development of fibrosis with resultant restrictive lung disease. Diagnosis is based on clinical features, exposure, imaging showing fibrosis, and pulmonary function tests showing a restrictive pattern of lung disease. A key feature of restrictive lung disease on pulmonary function testing is the preserved or increased ratio of FEV ,:FVC. (4 > (4 @ €C > m

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Pleural effusions occur because of multiple underlying conditions including infection such as empyema, pneumonia, malignancy such as lung cancer or mesothelioma, and increased hydrostatic pressure such as left-sided heart failure. They are clinically suspected when examination discloses dullness to percussion and diminished breath sounds, and they can be visualized on imaging including chest x-ray, computerized tomography, or ultrasonography. Clinical features such as immunocompromise, history of malignancy, or infectious symptoms or signs of sepsis such as fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, and lethargy can suggest the cause. Analyzing the pleural fluid can further inform the diagnosis. Pleural fluid is analyzed for cell count, organisms, pH, glucose, total protein, and enzyme concentrations. Decreased pH and decreased glucose concentration are indicative of increased cellular metabolism in the fluid and may indicate underlying malignancy and/or infection. Fluid can be further categorized as transudate (serous fluid resulting from imbalanced hydrostatic or oncotic pressure) or exudate (complex fluid resulting from pneumonia, empyema, malignancy, or inflammatory disease) using Light's criteria, which compares the pleural fluid protein and lactate dehydrogenase concentrations to those found in serum. explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Crohn disease is characterized by transmural inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract, most frequently involving the terminal ileum. It can arise anywhere in the gastrointestinal tract and is a subclass of inflammatory bowel disease. Most patients experience chronic abdominal cramping, bloody diarrhea, and weight loss. Examination often shows generalized abdominal tenderness, sometimes worse in the right lower quadrant, and extraintestinal manifestations such as uveitis. Severe Crohn disease can result in intestinal obstruction from stricture or inflammation, bowel perforation, intraabdominal abscess, and the formation of fistulas. Crohn disease may manifest with steatorrhea caused by the impairment of bile salt resorption secondary to inflammation of the terminal ileum. Bile salts play a crucial role in the solubilization of fats in the enteric lumen, and are recycled through the enterohepatic circulation, which is dependent on the resorption of bile salts through an intact ileal mucosa. Impairment of bile salt resorption because of ileal inflammation can overwhelm the ability of the liver to synthesize de novo bile acids, resulting in a deficiency in fat-soluble vitamin absorption. Patients with Crohn disease should undergo frequent evaluation for deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Sialadenitis refers to inflammation of the salivary gland and typically presents with acute onset of pain and swelling over the affected gland. Acute sialadenitis often persists for several weeks and most commonly occurs because of obstruction of the gland caused by sialolithiasis but may also occur secondary to viral infection (eg, mumps or Epstein-Barr virus), bacterial infection (most commonly with S. aureus), or strictures following radiotherapy. The presence of constitutional symptoms may be indicative of a viral cause, while the expression of purulent discharge from the glandular orifice may indicate a bacterial infection. This patient's history of pain initially precipitated by meals is most suggestive of the presence of a salivary gland stone causing intermittent obstruction. Further evaluation with ultrasonography or CT may help establish the diagnosis. Treatment is primarily conservative with analgesics, application of heat and massage, and hydration. Patients that fail to improve with conservative management sometimes require removal of a sialolith, if present, usually by sialoendoscopy.

29. An obese 42-year-old woman has an episode of colicky pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen that lasts 2 hours and subsides spontaneously. She has no fever or

leukocytosis and no signs of peritoneal irritation in the right upper quadrant. Liver function tests show no abnormalities. Ultrasonography shows gallstones. Which of the

following is the most likely cause of the abdominal pain?

question_stem: the most likely cause of the abdominal pain?

choices.text: Bacterial growth in bile within the common hepatic duct
Bacterial invasion of the gallbladder wall
Transitory chemical irritation of the gallbladder wall
Transitory obstruction of the common hepatic duct by gallstones

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's presenting symptom of colicky pain in the right upper quadrant is consistent with biliary colic secondary to transitory obstruction of the cystic duct by gallstones. The pain is typically dull, severe, triggered by meals, and may radiate to the right shoulder. If the gallstone is passed into the common bile duct, biliary obstruction may ensue and lead to jaundice, hepatic injury, and/or acute cholangitis. Most episodes of biliary colic last for several hours before subsiding spontaneously. Biliary colic can be distinguished from cholecystitis by a lack of fever, a normal abdominal examination, and a lack of leukocytosis. Abdominal ultrasonography can aid the diagnosis by identifying the presence of gallstones. Provided that the clinical picture and examination are improving, the acute management of biliary colic is generally conservative with oral analgesics. Elective cholecystectomy is recommended to prevent future complications from the gallstones. If symptoms of biliary colic progress to show features of jaundice, hepatic injury, cholecystitis, pancreatitis, choledocholithiasis, or cholangitis, operative (cholecystectomy) or interventional (eg, endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography) management should take place.

distractor_explanations.A: may result from an ascending infection of the biliary tree, known as cholangitis, which typically occurs in the setting of biliary instrumentation or choledocholithiasis. Acute cholangitis presents with fever and jaundice in addition to abdominal pain (Charcot triad) and possibly with shock and altered mental status (Reynolds pentad). Bacterial invasion of the gallbladder wall (
distractor_explanations.B: results in acute cholecystitis, which presents with fever, abdominal pain, and tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant, often in a patient with a history of gallstones. It is occasionally preceded by symptoms of biliary colic. Patients typically also present with leukocytosis. (4 > (4 @ tial > m

2 years ago, but he has had chronic mild midepigastric pain since that time. During his last hospitalization 2 years ago, an x-ray of the abdomen showed calcifications in the

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis may lead to chronic pancreatitis and insufficiency of both the exocrine and endocrine pancreatic functions. The exocrine pancreas produces digestive enzymes, the absence of which leads to malnutrition (eg, cachexia, muscle wasting), weight loss, vitamin deficiencies, and frequent, loose, foul-smelling, sometimes oily stools (steatorrhea). The endocrine pancreas produces insulin, glucagon, and somatostatin. The loss of endogenous insulin leads to the development of diabetes mellitus with symptoms including polyuria, polydipsia, and polyphagia. In this scenario, pancreatic production of insulin and glucagon are decreased, while peripheral insulin response is normal. The diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic insufficiency is through clinical history, imaging, and biopsy. Exocrine pancreatic insufficiency is treated with oral pancreatic enzyme and fat-soluble vitamin replacement. Additionally, the development of diabetes mellitus caused by the loss of pancreatic insulin requires insulin replacement. Any modifiable inciting causes of pancreatitis (eg, gallstones, alcohol abuse, hypertriglyceridemia, or hypercalcemia) should be mitigated to delay disease progression and preserve remaining native pancreatic function.

31. A 23-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 6-week history of fatigue and swelling of her eyelids, ankles, and feet. She has no history of serious illness and takes

no medications. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (120 Ib); BMI is 21 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows 2+ periorbital edema and 3+

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by edema secondary to excessive proteinuria resulting in hypoalbuminemia and diminished intravascular oncotic pressure. This occurs because of the loss of normal size and charge filtration of the glomerular capillary and Bowman capsule interface. Causes of nephrotic syndrome include minimal change disease, membranous nephropathy, and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children and can be idiopathic or triggered by a recent infection or immune stimulus. Patients classically present with dependent edema in the buttocks, lower back, and legs, foamy or dark-colored urine, hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, and proteinuria. Complications include hypercoagulability caused by the urinary loss of proteins such as antithrombin-3, which functions to inhibit coagulation factors II, VII, IX, X, XI, and XII. Deficiency of antithrombin-3 leads to hypercoagulability and would put this patient at high risk for thrombotic conditions such as deep venous thrombosis. Patients with nephrotic syndrome are also at an increased risk for infection because of the urinary loss of gamma globulins.

distractor_explanations.B: can present with peripheral edema, but often presents with a constellation of symptoms including fatigue, cold intolerance, weight gain, hyporeflexia, and dry, cool skin. Nephrolithiasis (
distractor_explanations.C: can occur in settings of increased formation of calcium oxalate, uric acid, cystine, or struvite crystals. Cystine crystals occur in patients with a hereditary defect of the renal proximal convoluted tubule that results in the decreased reabsorption of cystine, ornithine, lysine, and arginine. Uric acid calculi form most commonly in patients with hyperuricemia (eg, gout) and struvite calculi occur in the setting of infections caused by urease positive microbial pathogens, such as Klebsiella or Proteus species. explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Acute tubular necrosis is a cause of intrinsic acute renal failure that is most commonly the result of either ischemic or nephrotoxic insults to the kidneys. This patient presents after traumatic hemorrhagic shock with hemodynamic instability and signs of hypovolemia. This increases the risk for ischemic injury to the kidneys secondary to decreased renal blood flow, which can lead to tubular epithelial cell death and sloughing into the lumen of the tubules. This typically results in an initial oliguric phase where the patient is at increased risk for uremia, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis. Following this initial phase, the patient will then enter a polyuric, recovery phase characterized by excessive urine production with associated falls in creatinine and risk for electrolyte abnormalities, especially hypokalemia. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen are inhibitors of cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes, which have a primary role in the synthesis of prostaglandins and prostacyclins. explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's urinary retention, nighttime overflow incontinence, an enlarged prostate, and a weak urinary stream is suggestive of bladder outlet obstruction from benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). As shown in this patient, BPH can result in complications such as urinary tract infection, as evidenced by fever, dysuria, and white blood cells on urinalysis. In addition, severe bladder outlet obstruction can result in a postrenal acute kidney injury and increased serum creatinine level. The first appropriate step in management is relief of the bladder outlet obstruction by placement of a urinary catheter. The already narrowed prostatic urethra, if affected by secondary inflammation or infection, can result in near complete bladder outflow obstruction. Impaired drainage of the bladder and urethra predisposes to infection by limiting urinary washout of ascending pathogens, often enteric organisms.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Neisseria gonorrhoeae can cause vaginitis, cervicitis, and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) in women. It can also cause a multifocal dermatitis that typically presents with tender macular and/or pustular lesions along with disseminated and migratory polyarthritis. Risk factors for PID and other sexually transmitted infections include adolescence, multiple sexual partners, and not using barrier contraception such as condoms. Vaginitis typically presents with mucopurulent discharge and pruritus. Cervicitis presents with similar discharge but also with an erythematous, friable cervix and cervical motion tenderness on examination. When infection spreads to the fallopian tubes and ovaries, PID with purulent cervical discharge, uterine and adnexal tenderness, and systemic symptoms such as fever can result. If left untreated, PID can be complicated by tubo-ovarian or intraabdominal abscess, presenting with focal tenderness and a fluctuant mass. The antibiotic treatment of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection involves the use of third generation cephalosporins such as ceftriaxone, as well as concurrent treatment of Chlamydia trachomatis with doxycycline.

Primarily syphilis presents with a painless chancre (ulcer) of the genitalia. Secondary syphilis can present with macular, not pustular lesions of the hands and feet. examination, shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show a thyroid-stimulating hormone concentration of 23 yU/mL and free thyroxine concentration of 0.5 ng/dL

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's family history of a brother with type 1 diabetes mellitus is the most important historical clue because it suggests an increased risk for familial autoimmune disease. While there are many varieties of thyroid disease that can lead to hypothyroidism, the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-replete parts of the world is Hashimoto thyroiditis, also known as chronic autoimmune thyroiditis. Lymphocytic infiltration of the thyroid gland leads to cytotoxic destruction of the gland and subsequent fibrosis, which results in hypothyroidism. Patients may either have a goiter or a normal size thyroid gland. The diagnosis is made by measuring the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) concentration, which will be increased, and the free thyroxine concentration (FT,), which will be decreased. This pattern indicates adequate secretion of TSH from the pituitary gland but inadequate production of thyroxine in the thyroid gland. In some cases, patients may have antibodies against thyroid peroxidase or thyroglobulin, although these are not required for diagnosis. As this is an autoimmune disease, patients with a family history of other autoimmune disorders such as type 1 diabetes mellitus and primary adrenal insufficiency are at greater risk for developing chronic autoimmune thyroiditis. Treatment is with thyroid hormone replacement in the form of levothyroxine.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Deficiency of parathyroid hormone (PTH), also known as hypoparathyroidism, likely explains this patient's symptomatic hypocalcemia. PTH is a peptide hormone that increases osteoclast activity and bone resorption to maintain calcium homeostasis. It is produced by the four parathyroid glands, which are located on the posterior aspect of the thyroid gland. Primary hypoparathyroidism can occur following the unintentional resection of the parathyroid glands during thyroidectomy or may be caused by autoimmune destruction of the parathyroid glands. Primary hypoparathyroidism results in decreased concentrations of PTH, which leads to hypocalcemia secondary to inadequate bone resorption, hyperphosphatemia, and decreased concentrations of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol) because PTH stimulates renal conversion of 25-hydroxyvitamin D to its active form. explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient presents with signs and symptoms of toxic shock syndrome. Toxic shock syndrome toxin (TSST-1), produced by Staphylococcus aureus, causes a cytokine storm, which causes dysfunction of multiple organs and can lead to distributive shock and death. Patients typically present with fever, hypotension, diffuse erythematous rash, desquamation, and clinical and laboratory evidence of end organ dysfunction such as altered mental status, myalgia, thrombocytopenia, azotemia, and transaminitis. Toxic shock may be rapidly fatal, even with appropriate treatment. Treatment includes the administration of appropriate antibiotics, aggressive hemodynamic support with intravenous fluids, and support of end organ failure. Source control, such as a pelvic examination to remove a retained tampon, is important to limit further release of toxin.

This patient should first receive fluid resuscitation intravenously and be monitored for response. In addition, dopamine is not typically a first-line agent for vasoactive support because it is proarrhythmic. Norepinephrine is preferred as the initial pressor in the setting of septic shock. explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Granulomatous arteritis in cervical or temporal arteries, also referred to as temporal or giant cell arteritis is a vasculitis that affects the large vessels such as the aorta, aortic arch vessels, the temporal branch of the external carotid, and vertebral arteries, among others. It is characterized by headache, temporal tenderness, jaw claudication, and fever. A potential complication includes monocular blindness from ischemic optic neuropathy. This occurs secondary to inflammation and resultant thrombosis of the central retinal artery and/or posterior ciliary arteries. Because of this potential acute complication, this condition requires the urgent administration of glucocorticoids, ophthalmologic evaluation, and temporal artery biopsy for diagnosis. Administration of steroids does not generally affect biopsy results if biopsy occurs within 1 to 2 weeks.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Vasospasm causes the intermittent loss of blood flow to the distal extremities in Raynaud phenomenon, resulting in sequential white, blue, and red discoloration of the affected areas of skin. The vasospasm associated with Raynaud phenomenon can be triggered and exacerbated by cold temperature, stress, or emotional upset. Activities such as cigarette smoking, injury, trauma, or chemical exposure can put patients at a higher risk for Raynaud phenomenon. Raynaud phenomenon may be idiopathic or associated with mixed connected tissue disease, systemic lupus erythematosus, or CREST syndrome. When severe or prolonged, ischemic injury can result in digital ulcerations. Dressing warmly in cold weather can help prevent Raynaud phenomenon by decreasing cold exposure.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Heat stroke is characterized by an increased body temperature that occurs when the body is exposed to high environmental temperatures and high humidity. It commonly happens in young athletes or in elderly patients with impaired thermoregulatory capacity. Excessive heat exposure and increased core body temperature lead to cardiovascular and neurologic dysfunction with secondary tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotension. Vasodilation of superficial blood vessels may lead to shunting of blood with resultant multi-organ system dysfunction, including neurologic impairment, hepatic and renal ischemia, rhabdomyolysis, and disseminated intravascular coagulation. Treatment includes cooling of the patient with fans or ice water, continuous core temperature monitoring, and support of the patient’s airway, breathing, and circulation. A patient must demonstrate neurologic symptoms to diagnose heat stroke, whereas heat exhaustion presents similarly but with an intact neurologic examination. In this example, the patient is a young manual laborer who works outside in the sun; his use of an antihistamine (especially if it also has anticholinergic action) may also impair his ability to thermoregulate through sweat and cutaneous vasodilation.

44. A 24-year-old man who is employed as a landscaper is brought to the emergency department by a coworker 20 minutes after he collapsed while working in a garden; he had

light-headedness just before he lost consciousness. On arrival, he is responsive but is unable to give a medical history. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 125/min,

respirations are 28/min, and palpable systolic blood pressure is 70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Wheezes are heard bilaterally.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Administration of epinephrine is the most appropriate immediate step in management for this patient with presumed anaphylaxis. Anaphylaxis should be suspected given tachycardia, hypotension, hypoxia, and wheezing, which is most likely indicative of bronchospasm. Anaphylaxis is a Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction that develops following exposure to an allergen. It is caused by widespread IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation and is characterized by histaminergic responses within multiple organ systems leading to flushing, angioedema, bronchospasm, nausea, vomiting, abdominal discomfort, and vasodilation, which can lead to airway obstruction and circulatory collapse. If not managed promptly, death can occur from hypoxia and/or distributive shock. The diagnosis is made clinically, and the first treatment that should be given is intramuscular epinephrine. Adjunctive management may include inhaled B-adrenergic agonists, glucocorticoids, histamine blockers, fluid resuscitation, and potentially invasive airway or vasopressor support. Patients who present with signs and symptoms of anaphylaxis while working outdoors may have experienced bee envenomation. Regardless of the cause, treatment is the same. At the time of discharge, all patients should be provided with an epinephrine autoinjector and training on how to use it.

45. A 74-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital following a myocardial infarction. She is confused and has cool, clammy skin. Over the next hour, her blood pressure

decreases from 148/74 mm Hg to 80/40 mm Hg. Arterial blood gas analysis is most likely to show which of the following?

question_stem: most likely to show which of the following?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Following a myocardial infarction, hypotension, altered mental status, and hypoperfused (cool, clammy) skin is most likely caused by cardiogenic shock. Cardiogenic shock is caused by a decrease in cardiac output, often caused by infarcted or infected cardiac muscle. This leads to vasoconstriction of peripheral vessels to maintain blood pressure and inadequate perfusion of end organs. As organs begin to receive an insufficient supply of oxygen, they transition from aerobic metabolism to anaerobic metabolism, which leads to the production of lactic acid. This lactic acid decreases the pH of the blood, leading to a metabolic acidosis. This is often worsened in cardiogenic shock because the liver is unable to adequately metabolize lactate in the setting of decreased perfusion. Therefore, this patient likely has a metabolic acidosis caused by the production of lactic acid.

distractor_explanations.A: can be seen with primarily lung pathologies, such as an asthma or COPD exacerbation. However, prolonged hypoxemia often leads to a metabolic acidosis caused by an inadequate supply of oxygen to tissues, causing transition to anaerobic metabolism with consequent lactate production. This patient is more likely to have a metabolic acidosis related to decreased cardiac output than persistent hypoxemia with a normal pH. Metabolic alkalosis (
distractor_explanations.C: is often associated with the loss of acid, often from the gastrointestinal tract. For example, persistent emesis can cause metabolic alkalosis, as can the use of diuretics. This patient has no clear source of a loss of hydrogens ions, making metabolic alkalosis unlikely. Respiratory acidosis (
distractor_explanations.D: can be acute or chronic. Acute respiratory acidosis is often caused by hypoventilation, such as in the case of opioid-induced respiratory depression. Chronic, compensated respiratory acidosis is more commonly seen in patients with obstructive lung disease or obesity hypoventilation syndrome. This patient's cardiogenic shock would not lead to a respiratory acidosis. (4 > (4 @ tial > m

This can occur in cardiogenic shock, caused by a reduction in cardiac output secondary to infarcted or infected cardiac muscle. It can also occur in other forms of shock, such as hypovolemic or septic, also caused by the inadequate supply of oxygen to the body's tissues. (4 > (4 @ €C > m

1 month ago and is undergoing chemotherapy. A right subclavian central venous catheter is in place. His temperature is 38.9°C (102.1°F), pulse is 124/min, respirations are

24/min, and blood pressure is 104/68 mm Hg. Examination shows warm, flushed skin. The catheter site is slightly erythematous, and there is tenderness over the

subcutaneous pocket. His leukocyte count is 12,300/mm%. A chest x-ray shows a nodule in the right upper lobe. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Bacteremia commonly presents with fevers, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, and leukocytosis, and can also be associated with altered mental status and end organ damage if it proceeds to cause septic shock. While it can be caused by a variety of infections, such as pneumonia or pyelonephritis, it is most likely caused by this patient's central line given its erythematous and tender insertion site. Central line catheters are most often placed for the administration of vasopressors in critically ill patients, as an alternative for venous access in patients with difficult to obtain peripheral access, and for the long-term administration of medications, such as antibiotics or chemotherapy. Unfortunately, central line- associated bloodstream infections are a relatively common complication. Bacteria, most often skin flora such as staphylococcal species, can be introduced into the bloodstream and lead to bacteremia, especially in patients who are immunocompromised, such as this patient undergoing chemotherapy. Therefore, the most likely causal organism in this patient is Staphylococcus epidermidis, a common cutaneous organism that can translocate and seed discontinuities in skin such as line sites. Treatment includes intravenous antibiotics and removal of the line.

distractor_explanations.B: is a common pathogen in necrotizing skin infections, which present with fever, pain out of proportion to examination, erythema, ecchymosis, edema, and bullae, often in immunocompromised or diabetic patients. 47. A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician for HIV screening. She is asymptomatic. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She does not drink

alcohol or use illicit drugs. She has had two lifetime male sexual partners, and they used condoms consistently. Examination shows no abnormalities. An ELISA is positive for

HIV; the sensitivity of the ELISA is 95%, and the specificity is 90%. Which of the following represents the most appropriate sensitivity and specificity of an additional test to

confirm this patient's diagnosis?

Sensitivity Specificity

question_stem:
the most appropriate sensitivity and specificity of an additional test to

confirm this patient's diagnosis?

Sensitivity Specificity

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Sensitivity and specificity are important concepts when determining which diagnostic tests to utilize and how to interpret them. Sensitivity refers to the ability of a test to correctly identify those with the disease, whereas specificity refers to the ability of a test to correctly identify those without the disease. In a patient population with low prevalence of a disease, a negative result on a highly sensitive test can effectively rule out the disease because there is a low rate of false negative tests. However, a positive result on a sensitive test must be verified by a highly specific test, which would have a decreased risk for false positive results. Therefore, sensitive tests are often used for screening, as in this patient, but must be verified by a more specific test. Therefore, a test with 99% specificity would be most likely to confirm or refute this patient's diagnosis. Specificity is calculated as true negatives divided by the sum of true negatives and false positives. Therefore, a test with a 99% specificity would have only one false positive out of 100 administered tests. Positive tests would therefore be more likely to be true positives.
explanation.educational_objective: Sensitivity refers to the ability of a test to correctly identify those with the disease, whereas specificity refers to the ability of a test to correctly identify those without the disease. A highly sensitive test is useful for screening, whereas a highly specific test is useful for confirming the diagnosis. (4 > (4 @ tial > m

48. A study is conducted to assess a possible association between regular use of alcohol and colon cancer. Cases consist of patients hospitalized with colon cancer; controls
consist of age- and gender-matched patients admitted to the same hospital for treatment of an acute injury. Cases and controls are interviewed after their conditions stabilize.
The researchers conclude that regular use of alcohol reduced the risk of colon cancer. Which of the following is the most important reason to be concerned about the authors'
conclusion?

choices.text: Lack of incidence rates for alcohol users and nonusers
Lack of incidence rates for alcohol users and nonusers

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: A variety of methodological flaws or study weaknesses can limit the application of study results to a general population. These flaws include confounding variables, inappropriate selection of case or control groups, inappropriate analysis of data, and biases, such as sampling bias and observation bias. In designing a case control study to determine relationships between exposures and outcomes, it is important to choose a case group and a control group that are matched to eliminate or avoid confounding to strengthen conclusions that differences observed are caused by the variables being studied. For example, in this scenario, choosing a control population that consists of patients admitted to the hospital with acute injuries likely interferes with the interpreted results of the studies that the regular use of alcohol reduced the risk for colon cancer. This is because regular alcohol use can lead to acute injuries during intoxication, and thus the control group may have a higher baseline use of alcohol compared to the case group. This has likely led to the possible inappropriate conclusion in this study that regular use of alcohol reduced the risk for colon cancer. Therefore, the most important reason to be concerned about the authors' conclusion of this study is the inappropriate control group.

This group can then be interviewed about their use of alcohol, which can be compared to the use of alcohol in an appropriate control group to determine whether regular alcohol use is linked to the development of colon cancer. Lack of incidence rates for alcohol users and nonusers (

49. A77-year-old man has had intermittent confusion since transfer from the hospital to hospice care 6 days ago. His blood pressure has ranged between 90/45 mm Hg and
70/20 mm Hg during this period. He was treated in the hospital for a myocardial infarction sustained 3 weeks ago. During the past 8 years, he has been admitted to the
hospital four times for myocardial infarction. He has been treated unsuccessfully for atrial and ventricular arrhythmias and has been unable to tolerate inotropic agents. He
has had left hemiparesis since he sustained a stroke 30 years ago. His physician has explained to him and his family that he is not a candidate for cardiac transplant or
implant of a left ventricular assistance device. The patient has severe chronic back pain. His only medication is morphine. The patient's advance directive designates his
daughter as his health care proxy, and the patient has explained that he wants his daughter to make medical decisions for him. The daughter says that the hospice care is
insufficient in controlling her father's pain and asks that he be admitted to the hospital. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Hospice care is a form of health care that aims to provide comfort and palliation to terminally ill patients in their last stages of life. As a terminally ill patient approaches the end of life, they may decide to focus on the quality of remaining life rather than on increasing the quantity of time remaining. Hospice is a multidisciplinary healthcare model that includes physicians, nurses, social workers, and chaplains and aids to eliminate suffering and provide spiritual and emotional support to patients and their family. Goals often include treating symptoms, such as pain and anxiety, and providing a patient as much time at home as possible by avoiding further hospital admissions. This patient has terminal heart failure associated with arrhythmias, as well as hemiparesis, and has opted to enroll in hospice care. Therefore, care should be taken to eliminate the symptoms related to this patient's chronic illnesses by discussing the patient's pain control with the hospice staff, rather than admitting him to the hospital again.

The purpose of hospice care is to alleviate pain and suffering at the end of a patient's life by minimizing hospital admissions, as well as diagnostic and invasive procedures. Medications provided during hospice care are often titrated to patient symptoms, with appropriate pain control being an important tenet. (4 > (4 @ tial > m
